text_description: Katipuneros led by Andres Bonifacio at Tandang Sora’s residence in Bahay Toro tear up their cedulas personales to declare rebellion against Spain.

text_headline: After receiving news of the excellent qualities of Manila Bay as harbour and the extnsive rice fields near it, Legazpi moves to Manila.
text_description: After receiving news of the excellent qualities of Manila Bay as harbor and the extensive rice fields near it, Legazpi moves to Manila.

media_caption: Cover of the 1961 facsimile edition of Jose Rizal’s El Filibusterismo, 1891, featuring gomburza
text_description: The Cavite Mutiny is used by Spanish authorities to deport or imprison several Filipino priests and businessmen. Three priests leading the campaign for secularization, Gomez, Burgos, and Zamora, are executed by garrote in Bagumbayan, an event that would influence Jose Rizal and other writers.

media_caption: Antonio Luna, Headshot, Literary figures during the Spanish period
text_description: Antonio Luna founds La Independencia, a revolutionary newspaper, staffed by, among others, Rafael Palma (1874-1939), Fernando Ma. Guerrero (1873-1929), and Epifanio de los Santos (1871-1928).

media_caption: La Solidaridad, 1895, the outlet for propagandist literature in the late 19th century
media_credit: (from the Jose Victor Z. Torres Collection)
text_description: The first issue of La Solidaridad is published. The newspaper will publish reformist pieces until its final issue, dated Nov 15, 1895.

media_caption: Reformist writer Jose Rizal
text_description: Rizal founds La Liga Filipina. He is arrested and detained in Fort Santiago on July 6.

media_caption: A Thomasite and her class
media_credit: (Mr. and Ms. Collection, Ateneo de Manila University Rizal Library)
text_description: The first batch of “Thomasites” arrives in the Philippines aboard the USS Thomas, heralding the beginning of the public school system and the teaching of the English language and American culture, through which, according to Renato Constantino (1919-99) in “The Miseducation of the Filipino,” the colonial government reshaped the Filipino mind.

media_caption: Leaders of  the Katipunan Gregoria de Jesus and Andres Bonifacio
media_credit: Photos from Ambeth R. Ocampo Collection
text_description: Andres Bonifacio and others found the Kataastaasan Kagalang-galang na Katipunan ng mga Anak ng Bayan (Katipunan/KKK), which, unlike the Filipino propagandists in Spain, has as one of its aims the separation of the Philippines from Spain.

media_caption: Prewar Manila Hotel
text_description: The Manila Hotel is inaugurated. It will become the venue for events that feature important orchestras and bands of Manila.

media_caption: Municipal Hall of Jaro, Iloilo, restored in 2017 by the National Museum
text_description: The diocese of Jaro in Iloilo is created by dividing Cebu. Jaro’s jurisdiction covers Western Visayas and Mindanao. Mariano Cuartero, OP (1813-1884) is appointed in 1857 as the first bishop of the new diocese but does not take possesion of the see until 1868.

media_caption: Tulay, an important outlet for Chinese-Filipino literature published by the KAISA para sa Kaunlaran
text_description: The Kaisa Para sa Kaunlaran is established. Apart from the newsletter Tulay, it will publish collections of Filipino-Chinese writings and address the concerns of the Filipino-Chinese community, including the many “kidnap for ransom” cases in the 1990s.
The 55-volume Philippine Islands, 1493-1898, a collection of important documents from the Spanish colonial period edited by Emma Helen Blair and James A. Robertson, is released.
Ms Redgrave experiments radio broadcast from Nichols Air Base. She will be followed in the same year by Henry Herman.
Student demonstrators take over the UP Diliman campus in what is known as the Diliman Commune.

media_caption: Crowd in panic during the Plaza Miranda bombing, Manila, 21 Aug 1971
text_description: Bombs are lobbed at the Liberal Party (LP) rally in Plaza Miranda, killing nine people and wounding LP members.
The military arrest suspected subversives and Marcos’s political enemies. Broadcast media, print media, theater performances, and films are controlled.

media_caption: El Renacimiento, Politically oriented periodicals
media_credit: (Biblioteca Nacional de España, University of Michigan, and UP Diliman Main Library)
text_description: The newspaper El Renacimiento is founded by Rafael Palma. It later acquires a Tagalog version called Muling Pagsilang. The newspaper becomes an outlet of anti-Americanism.
Nur Misuari establishes the Moro National Liberation Front.

media_caption: Bisaya (Cebuano), one of the lines of magazines by The Ramon Roces
text_description: The magazine Bisaya is founded, with Vicente Padriga (1895-1980) as editor.

media_caption: Hiligaynon (Ilonggo), one of the lines of magazines by The Ramon Roces
text_description: The magazine Ang Bisaya sa Hiligaynon, later renamed Hiligaynon, is founded, with Abe Gonzales as its first editor.

media_caption: Bannawag (Ilokano), one of the lines of magazines by The Ramon Roces
text_description: The magazine Bannawag is founded and becomes an important main venue for literature in Ilocano.

media_caption: Liwayway (Tagalog), one of the lines of magazines by The Ramon Roces
text_description: Liwayway and other publications resume operations.

media_caption: KZRM shortwave listening QSL card,  signed by managing director Carlos P. Romulo, ca 1930
media_credit: Photo courtesy of Amateur Radio Station
text_description: Herman’s radio station KZKZ is transferred to Radio Corporation of the Philippines and is bought by the Radio Corporation of America, which operates it as KZRM.
Jazz bebop emerges in the USA, which continues until 1958; this becomes popular in the Philippines in the late 1940s.
The Philippine National Music Council is founded on March 25 under the auspices of United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organizations (UNESCO) – International Music Council (IMC).

media_caption: Dely Magpayo on the set of Mga Liham Kay Tiya Dely, 1958
text_description: Dely Magpayo begins her counselling radio program in DZRH.

media_caption: vTawag ng Tanghalan hosts Patsy and Lopito with grand champion Diomedes Maturan, 1958
media_credit: Pinoy Television: The Story of ABS-CBN: The Medium of Our Lives, edited by Thelma Sioson-San Juan. ABS-CBN Broadcasting, 1999.
text_description: Tawag ng Tanghalan first airs on radio and, in 1957, on television. It launches the singing careers of Pepe Pimentel (aka Jose Gonzales), Diomedes Maturan, Cenon Lagman, Novo Bono, Nora Aunor, and Ric Manrique Jr, among others.
Elvis Presley, the “King of Rock’n’Roll,” releases his first album with the song “Heartbreak Hotel” topping the charts thereafter.
The Institute of National Language issues the Tagalog text of Pambansang Awit ng Pilipinas (Philippine National Anthem).

media_caption: James Reuter's The Sound of Music, St. Paul's College, Manila, 1964
media_credit: St. Paul University of Manila College of Music and the Performing Arts Collection
text_description: The Fleur-de-Lis Auditorium of St Paul College Manila opens; it will be known as a venue of Broadway musicals such as Sound of Music, South Pacific, King and I, and Carousel, directed by Fr. James Reuter (1916-2012) or Daisy Avellana (1917-2013).
Muslim rebels continue their military operations in Sulu Archipelago and Mindanao
Afro-Cuban jazz such as mambo for big bands becomes popular. Another Afro-Cuban music chacha follows its rise to popularity.

media_caption: Kennon Road to Baguio, popularly known as the Zigzag, ca 1915
text_description: The Spanish explore Baguio and surroundings. Appointed Gobernador politico-militar of Baguio is Don Manuel Scheidnagel. La Trinidad is chosen as the capital.

media_caption: Binondo canal, Manila, ca 1920
text_description: Gov-Gen Luis Dasmariñas (r.1593-1596) acquires the encomienda de Binondo or Minondoc from its encomendero Antonio de Velada. He donates land for a church and hospital, for the Dominican mission to the Chinese Christians in Binondo.

media_caption: Salvador P. Lopez at an assembly at the Quezon Hall lobby, University of the Philippines Diliman, during the First Quarter Storm, 1970
text_description: A series of anti-Marcos and anti-US protests, collectively known as the First Quarter Storm (FQS), rocks the country. The First Quarter Storm, which is named for a series of student protests and riots, begins after Marcos's State of the Nation Address at Congress on Jan 30, when demostrating students clash with the police.
Rock ‘n’ roll, American popular music based on Afro-American music, is disseminated worldwide, particularly Bill Haley’s “Rock Around the Clock” (1955).
Afro-Cuban rumba spreads internationally.

media_caption: Presidents Manuel L. Quezon, 1948, by Fernando Amorsolo
media_credit: (Copyright owned by the Fernando C. Amorsolo Art Foundation, Inc)
text_description: The Philippine Commonwealth government is inaugurated, with Manuel Quezon as president and Sergio Osmeña as vice president. It starts a ten-year countdown to independence.
Eugenio Lopez II and Sergio Osmeña III escape from prison and flee to the US.

media_caption: Gawad CCP Para sa Sining (Musika) awardees, Aurelio Estanislao, awarded in 1978
media_credit: CCP Collection, Filipinas Heritage Library,  Fanny Aldaba-Lim, Pablo Tariman, Ryan Cayabyab
text_description: The Philippine Jaycees gives the first Ten Outstanding Young Men (TOYM) award for music to baritone Aurelio Estanislao (1923-1978) during its inaugural ceremony. In subsequent years, Oscar Yatco (1960), Gilopez Kabayao (1961), and Benjamin Tupas (1962) get the distinction.
Jose Ma. Sison, CPP-NPA head, is captured. A military commission finds detainees Benigno Aquino Jr., Bernabe “Kumander Dante” Buscayno, and Victor Corpus guilty of subversion.
In mid-1960s, reggae evolves in Jamaica from a blend of American R&B, traditional African and Jamaican folk music, and ska.
The Republic Cultural Heritage is instituted by the government to “establish a standard of excellence which would serve both as an incentive and goal for the future generation.”
The Philippine Government, the MNLF, and the Islamic Conference sign the Tripoli Agreement which provides for an autonomous region for Muslims in Southern Philippines among its provisions.

media_caption: She's dating the gangster by Sgwannabe aka Bianca Bernardino, 2014, Wattpad story published as books
text_description: Engineer Benjie Tan becomes the first Filipino to access the Internet. As of 2017 there are about 60 million internet users in the country. This Internet will affect the circulation and production of Philippine literature, resulting in such forms as pop fiction on platforms like Wattpad. The e-mail engenders possibilities for the epistolary form.
Congress passes the Music Law, an act that emphasizes the importance of teaching music in elementary and secondary schools.
Japanese Daisuke Inoue (b 1940) invents the karaoke machines in Kobe bars.

media_caption: Evita, Repertory Philippines, Manila, 1986
text_description: Zenaida Amador establishes Repertory Philippines, which will bring Broadway musicals to the country such as My Fair Lady, Hello, Dolly, and Evita in the ensuing decades.
Gabriela Silang, wife of Diego Silang who succeeds her husband as leader of the revolt, is killed.

media_caption: Scene from Noli Me Tangere, 1987
text_description: Rizal’s birth centenary is celebrated, with many contests and commissions in music.

media_caption: Vic Silayan and Lily Gamboa, center, with Lolita Rodriguez and Nick Lizaso, in PETA’s Bayaning Huwad, Dulaang Rajah Sulayman, Manila, 1967
media_credit: Romy Vitug, National Library of the Philippines Collection
text_description: The Philippine Educational Theater Association is founded and later produces original sarsuwela and musicals.
Zarzuela Foundation of the Philippines, Inc., is established under Proclamation No. 832, with Teodoro Valencia as Chair.
To flush out MNLF-Bangsa Moro rebels, government armed forces bombard Jolo and raze the ancient commercial capital to the ground. Countless civilians are killed and rendered homeless.
Pres. Marcos stops the construction of the 1.1 billion peso Bataan nuclear power which is being opposed by many sectors of society.

text_headline: Bataan falls to the Japanese.
text_description: Bataan falls to the Japanese.
The Beatles begin to penetrate the music industry’s charts.
Salsa dancing becomes popular among the Caribbean immigrants in New York City.
Philips company releases compact cassette tapes in the market.

In another scene, hip-hop music, utilizing rap, LP record scratching, breakdancing, and graffiti evolves in the street parties of youths of Caribbean origin in South Bronx, New York. It will come to the Philippines in the early 1980s.
The National Democratic Front and the Christians for National Liberation are organized as a broad coalition allied with the Communist Party of the Philippines.

media_caption: Hotdog band
text_description: Hotdog band’s hit single “Manila” becomes the coined name of Original Pilipino Music. Dubbed as Manila Sound, it also defines the disco trend that sweeps all over the Philippines, with the rise of other groups such as VST & Co., APO Hiking Society, Boyfriends, and Hagibis.

media_caption: Imelda Marcos, center, with the winner and candidates of Miss Universe 1974
text_description: The Miss Universe beauty pageant inaugurates the Folk Arts Theater, which will become an important venue for pop concerts.

media_caption: Web banner for Rappler’s Live Jam, a live streaming program, featuring Rocksteddy, 2015
text_description: The Broadcast Media Council (BMC) issues Memorandum Order No. 75-31 requiring all radio stations to play at least one Filipino song every hour. This will give a boost to the creation and popularization of Original Pilipino Music (OPM).

media_caption: Main maritime roads during the Song and Yuan Dynasties
text_description: The Chinese annals titled “Account of the Various Barbarians ” by Zhao Rugua mentions the Philippines as the land of Ma-i (also Ma’i, May-i, Mayi or Maidh), which trades with Brunei and with Song and Ming China.
Disco dancing using recorded mix and emphasizing thumping bass in straight 4/4 meter becomes a worldwide phenomenon.
The first rap single “Rapper’s Delight” reaches the Top 40.

text_headline: FM radio station NU 107 closes down.
text_description: FM radio station NU 107 closes down.
Broadcast Media Council (BMC) is dissolved and radio stations go back to airing mostly American hits.
Philips and Sony co-develop digital optical disc (CD) storage.

media_caption: Title page of the 1899 editions of Jose Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere
text_description: The centennial of Jose Rizal’s novel Noli Me Tangere is celebrated.

media_caption: Plaza Salcedo, with Salcedo Obelisk, fountain, and Vigan Cathedral, 2016
media_credit: (Photo by Jesse Alegre, Government of Vigan City)V
text_description: Juan de Salcedo (1549-1576) founds Villa Fernandina (Vigan), Ilocos Sur.

media_caption: Municipal Hall of Taal, Batangas, formerly its casa real, 2012
text_description: Taal town is established by the Augustinians.

media_caption: Francisco V. Coching, Lapu-Lapu and Magellan, 1974
text_description: Magellan is killed in the battle of Mactan, led by Lapu-lapu.
The Folk Arts Theater (FAT), later called Tanghalang Francisco Balagtas, opens as the setting of the Miss Universe beauty pageant, and as the venue for folkloric arts.
Sultan Dipatuan Kudarat, the 7th sultan of Maguindanao fights Spanish invasion, resisting occupation of Mindanao and conducting attacks on Luzon and Visayas.

media_caption: San Agustin Church in Intramuros, Manila, 1993
media_credit: (Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection)
text_description: Legazpi dies and his remains are interred in San Agustin; Guido Lavesares succeeds as governor-general.
MPEG-1 Layer 3 (MP3) becomes the international standard in audio compression.

media_caption: Pro-Cory Aquino rally at Luneta, Manila, with crowds singing “Bayan Ko”
media_credit: Bayan Ko! Images of the Philippine Revolt by Project 28 Days, Ltd., 1986.
text_headline: PEOPLE POWER
text_description: The People Power Revolution ensues leading to Marcos's ouster.
Violinist “Coke” Bolipata establishes Casa San Miguel Foundation, which trains young artists and musicians.

media_caption: President Carlos P. Garcia
media_credit: (Copyright owned by the Fernando C. Amorsolo Art Foundation, Inc)
text_description: President Carlos Garcia’s “Filipino First Policy,” which gives priority to Filipino commercial ventures, is approved by the National Economic Council.

media_caption: Gen Douglas MacArthur delivering a speech during the inauguration of the third Philippine republic, 1946, and behind him, from left to right, former president Sergio Osmeña, Pres Manuel Roxas, and US High Commissioner Paul McNutt
text_description: Gen Douglas MacArthur withdraws his troops to Corregidor, and later Australia.

media_caption: Macli-ing Dulag, Kalinga chieftain killed for leading the protest against the construction of dams.
media_credit: (Photo by Lin Neumann in Macli-ing Dulag: Kalinga Chief Defender of the Cordillera by Ma. Ceres P. Doyo.  University of the Philippines Press, 2015.)
text_description: Macli-ing Dulag, the leader of the Kalinga Butbut subgroup which opposes the Chico River Dam project, is killed by government troops.
The Associated Broadcasting Company (TV5) is founded.
The Cebu Youth Symphony Orchestra (later renamed Peace Philharmonic Orchestra) is founded under the auspices of the Salvador and Pilar Sala Foundation, Inc.
The authoritarian government initiates the program to turn local rituals, symbols, and traditions into events with pageantry to promote tourism and showcase progress under the New Society.
Ferdinand Marcos is elected president of the Philippines.
The Philippines celebrates the centennial of its independence from Spain with competitions and many commissions.
Ferdinand Marcos begins his second term as president.

media_caption: An illustration based on “Nilumtoh Yay Nay Pinatubo” (Mount Pinatubo Erupted Now),a first-person narrative about the explosion of Mount Pinatubo in 1991
text_description: Mt. Pinatubo erupts affecting Central Luzon, pouring lahar into many communities in Pampanga, Zambales, and Pampanga. It is considered the second biggest volcanic eruption of the 20th century.

Eighty traditional artists and groups travel to Washington DC for a collaborative festival from June to July that is sponsored by the Smithsonian Institution and the Cultural Center of the Philippines.
The first Betamax videocassette tape is introduced in the United States.

Rebel officers led by Colonel Gregorio “Gringo” Honasan occupy army headquarters as part of an attempted military coup d’etat. The coups continue up to 1989. Honasan is arrested and imprisoned, but escapes later on.
The other groups of missionaries arrive in the Philippines: Franciscans, 1578; Jesuits, 1581; Dominicans, 1587; and Recollects, 1606.

Members of the Reform the Armed Forces Movement led by Honasan stage another coup against the Aquino government. Rebel troops seize several military bases and two broadcast stations in Manila. US Pres George Bush backs the Aquino government and sends fighter planes over the city to intimidate the rebel soldiers.

media_caption: Arzobispado de Nueva Segovia in Vigan, Ilocos Sur, 2012
text_description: Manila becomes an archdiocese with the following suffragan dioceses: Nueva Segovia (formerly in Lal-lo, Cagayan, later transferred to Vigan), Nueva Caceres (Naga), and Cebu. Cebu is territorially the most extensive because it includes all of the Visayan islands and Mindanao. In the latter half of the 17th century, the Marianas and Guam are also added to the diocese of Cebu.
Music-video programming Myx first airs on Studio 23.

media_caption: View of Dapitan
media_credit: (Colorized by Kiko del Rosario, Philippine Picture Post Cards: 1900-1920 by Jonathan Best, The Bookmark, Inc, 1994)
text_description: Jesuit vice-provincial for the Pintados (Visayas) Pedro Gutierrez, SJ (1593-1651) makes Dapitan a central house or residencia for Zamboanga.
Gov Gen Dasmarinas orders the documentation of the native inhabitants.
Jorge B. Vargas and Aurelio Alvero collect Filipino artworks.

media_caption: Colegio de San Juan de Letran, 1887
text_description: Colegio de San Juan de Letran is founded as Colegio de Huerfanos de San Juan de Letran by Capt. Juan Rodrigo Jeronimo Guerrero, chiefly for orphaned boys of military personnel. In 1640, the school is merged with the Colegio de Huerfanos de San Jose y San Pablo, founded by Bro. Diego de Santa Maria. The merged school, which comes to be known as San Juan de Letran, is placed under Dominican administration.

media_caption: Banaue Rice Terraces, ca 1990
text_description: The rice terraces are built by the Ifugao.
Leonel Vandellon launches what is probably the first Filipino net label QED Records, which caters to indie musicians.

media_caption: Manunggul jar
text_description: The predecessors of the Palawan and the Tagbanwa dwell in the Tabon caves and practice jar burial, as evidenced by the Manunggul jar.

media_caption: Imelda, 2003
text_description: President Aquino allows the return of Imelda Marcos to the Philippines after a five-year exile to face graft and tax evasion charges.
The Hindu temple complex of Prambanan is built in honor of Shiva, Vishnu, and Brahma, adorned with bas reliefs of dancing apsaras and scenes from Ramayana.
Angkor Wat or “temple city” is built as a Hindu shrine sculpted with images of dancing apsaras.

media_caption: Arzobispado de Nueva Segovia in Vigan, Ilocos Sur, 2012
text_description: Authorization to transfer seat of the diocese of Nueva Segovia from Lal-lo in Cagayan to Vigan, Ilocos Sur, is granted because Vigan is more accessible by boat than Lal-lo.

media_caption: Map: Philippine archipelago
text_description: Multiple Austronesian Migrations (from Taiwan) to the Philippine Archipelago begin.

media_caption: Spanish-period San Juan de Dios Hospital in Intramuros
text_description: The administration of a hospital founded in 1578 in Manila by Juan Clemente OFM is given to the brothers of San Juan de la Dios. It is renamed Hospital de San Juan de Dios.
Pythagoras of Samos (570-495 BC) and Aristoxenus of Tarentum (c. 375- 335 BC) discover the harmonic system.

media_caption: Pro-Cory Aquino rally at Luneta, Manila, with crowds singing “Bayan Ko”
media_credit: Bayan Ko! Images of the Philippine Revolt by Project 28 Days, Ltd., 1986.
text_description: Elections for the Batasang Pambansa are held. As expected, opposition candidates are defeated by Marcos’s KBL candidates. Noise barrages signal the people’s protest.

media_caption: Relief of Nuestra Señora del Pilar
text_description: Jesuits evangelize Zamboanga.

media_caption: Municipal Hall of Taal, Batangas, formerly its casa real, 2012
text_description: Taal becomes the capital of Batangas.
Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo is elected president after controversial elections.
Gov. Gen. Sebastian Hurtado de Corcuera executes the order from Philip IV to punish and stop Muslim pirates.
China codifies the wu-yin system of five tones.
The first DVD player is created by Sony Company.
Gregorian chant is codified.
Apart from prophets, angels, and other celestials, the Islamic belief in spirits created from “smokeless fire” called jinn which can possess humans, is introduced.

media_caption: Polkabal, a fusion of polka and balse or waltz, ca 1930
media_credit: Philippine National Dances by Francisca Reyes-Aquino, Aquino, F. R. 1996
text_description: The dance waltz from Germany and Austria becomes the most favored ballroom dance genre in the modern world.
The centennial of the Philippine Revolution against Spain is celebrated.

media_caption: Calle Crisologo at Vigan’s Mestizo district, 2016
text_description: Villa Fernandina (Vigan) is elevated to the status of ciudad or city.
Country blues emerges in Mississippi Delta and East Texas from 1890-1905.
Emile Berliner (1851-1929) introduces recording technology using flat disks that later evolved into shellac and vinyl records.
Busan International Film Festival is established and will later on feature many Filipino films in both its competitions and exhibitions.
Based on tarsilas (genealogies), Muslim settlements are found in Sulu.

media_caption: View of Dapitan
media_credit: Colorized by Kiko del Rosario, Philippine Picture Post Cards: 1900-1920 by Jonathan Best. The Bookmark, Inc, 1994.
text_headline: Dr. Jose Rizal (1861-1898) is exiled to Dapitan.
text_description: Dr. Jose Rizal (1861-1898) is exiled to Dapitan. From July 1892 to March 1893 he is under house arrest in the casa real. But after winning a national lottery, he purchases property in Talisay, where he is allowed to live.
Warner Music Philippines, Sony BMG, and EMI close down.

media_caption: Santo Niño de Cebu
media_credit: (Photo from The Augustinian Province of Santo Niño de Cebu-Philippines Provincialate Offices)
text_description: Amid the ruins, an image of the Santo Niño, believed to be the one given by Magellan to Juana, is found among native icons. The child’s image is placed in the first church called Santisimo Nombre de Jesus built by the Agustinians, the first Catholic friars to come to the Philippines.
Mexico declares independence from Spain, ending the annual situado, an amount of money which supports the operations of the colonial government.

media_caption: Partners dancing the tango, Fiesta Pavillion, Manila, ca 1960
text_description: Tango, an urban song and dance from Argentina, emerges from the poor neighborhoods in Buenos Aires.
European and American ships begin to buy raw agricultural products from the Philippines, enriching the Spaniards and mestizos who owned lands planted with these crops.
Silent moving picture images are shown for the first time by Leibman and Perritz in Escolta with musical numbers by Francisco de P. Barbat.
A Spanish royal decree opens the colonial economy to international trade. Two American companies are established in Manila.
The impeachment trial against President Estrada begins.

Friars are powerful in the colonial regime. Gov-Gen Diego de Salcedo is forced to vacate his position and is imprisoned by armed friars and soldiers led by Fray Jose de Paternina, for refusing to appoint the latter’s nephew as alcalde.
Paul P. de la Gironiere, a French traveler who settled in Jala-Jala, Rizal, publishes his book Twenty Years in the Philippines [1819-1839] in New York, translated from the original French.
Manila is being remodeled as an American urban center. American establishments and structures are being built.

The Santa Ana Cabaret along H. Santos Street in Makati is built to cater to US soldiers and the moneyed class of Manila. The large cabaret, advertised as the largest dance hall in the world, boasts of the best dancing music performed by bands and orchestras.

media_caption: Jazz band with Lito Molina on the alto sax, left, Angel Peña on the upright bass, behind,  and Emil Mijares at the piano, among others, ca 1965
text_description: An eclectic style developed by Black Americans called jazz emerges from 1890s to 1910s.
Thomas Edison (1847-1931) invents the phonograph.
Spanish religious document the native cultures in the islands.
The habanera from the Spanish zarzuela Viaje Redondo by Massaguer and librettists Regino Escalera and Federico Casedemunt is published in Le Tour du Monde.
The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics or Soviet Union is established. Many artists from the czarist regime leave the socialist State.

media_caption: Bikol edition of Ani, edited by Marjorie M. Evasco, 1988
text_description: The new CCP management reorients the institution to emphasize Filipinization, democratization, and decentralization. It gives grants for literature and publishes the literary journal Ani.
Quezon and Osmeña are reelected.

media_caption: President Macario Sakay, seated second from right, and the top generals of the Republika ng Katagalugan, 1906
media_credit: (National Historical Commission of the Philippines, Wikimedia Commons)
text_description: Aguinaldo is captured in Palanan, Isabela and swears allegiance to the United States. Mabini and others who refused to take the oath of allegiance are exiled. The Americans establish a civil government, but guerilla resistance continues throughout the first decade of the new century.

media_caption: President Diosdado Macapagal by Romeo Enriquez, 1962
text_description: Diosdado Macapagal, a Kapampangan writer and actor, is elected president of the Philippines and serves until 1965.
President Arroyo declares “State of Rebellion” in Manila following riots instigated by supporters of ousted president Estrada.
A nationwide plebiscite grants women the right to vote.
To prepare for the increasing threat of Japanese imperialist invasion of Asia, the Philippine National Assembly establishes the Department of National Defense.
To consolidate the landlord classes, organizations like the Mancomunidad Pampangueña and the Kahirup of Negros Occidental composed of sugar barons are organized.

media_caption: Michael Fajatin, second from left, and Jessica Soho, center, interviewing Bagong Alyansang Makabayan  Secretary-General Teddy Casiño, far left, during the 2001 EDSA Revolt
text_description: Estrada’s trial is aborted, leading to a second EDSA Revolt, which installs Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo, then the vice president, into power. Estrada’s followers will stage a protest at EDSA in April but will be suppressed.

media_caption: Maj Isabelo Abaya, center with cane, and his Igorot recruits  during the Philippine-American War, Candon, Ilocos Sur, 1899
text_headline: The Fil-American war begins.
text_description: The San Juan Bridge incident ignites the Philippine-American war and will continue until 1907.

media_caption: Parade of Emilio Aguinaldo and his retinue across the main plaza of Malolos on their way to Barasoain Church in 23 Jan 1899
text_description: The first Philippine Republic is proclaimed in Malolos.

media_caption: Santa Isabel College in Manila
text_description: Colegio de Santa Isabel for girls is established.
The big studios—Sampaguita Pictures, LVN Pictures, and Premiere Productions, Inc.—produce films of all genres, including the musical.
Antonio Trillanes IV leads a military mutiny at the Peninsula Manila.
The moneyed and educated ilustrado begin to travel to Spain and Europe for their education.

media_caption: Black Nazarene of Quiapo
media_credit: (Photo from Quiapo Church Social Communications Department)
text_description: Three images of the Jesus Nazareno from Mexico arrive and are given to the Recollects. One, subsequently given to Quiapo, is the best known.
The Japanese execute 26 Catholic religious and laymen who preach Christianity in Nagasaki, Japan. The event becomes the subject for comedias later.
Hundreds of Huk guerrillas and members of the Partido Komunista ng Pilipinas surrender after the organization is outlawed.

media_caption: Robert Stewart, host of Uncle Bob’s Lucky 7 Club, 1961
media_credit: (Pinoy Television, The Story of ABS-CBN: The Medium of Our Lives, edited by Thelma Sioson-San Juan. ABS-CBN Broadcasting, 1999.)
text_description: TV sets become one of the most in-demand appliances in urban areas. DZBB-TV Channel 7 starts broadcasting, established by the Republic Broadcasting System owned by Robert Stewart. The government-owned Philippine Broadcast Service Channel also begins its broadcast.

text_headline: WILLIAM HOWARD TAFT
text_description: William Howard Taft assumes office as first civil govenor.

text_headline: MANILA: OPEN CITY
text_description: Japanese forces enter Manila, previously declared an "Open City" to protect it from destruction and to secure its inhabitants. The Japanese occupation of the Philippines begins and lasts until 1945.

media_caption: American-period Philippine Normal School in Manila
text_description: The Philippine Normal School is opened, to train teachers for the public school system established by the Americans

media_caption: Plaza Libertad, Iloilo
text_headline: ILOILO'S INDEPENDENCE
text_description: Philippine flag is raised at Plaza Libertad, Iloilo to proclaim Philippine independence from Spain and in defiance of the America's actions.

text_headline: Forced or corvee labor is instituted in the Philippines.
text_description: Forced or corvee labor is instituted in the Philippines.

media_caption: Pres Ferdinand E. Marcos declaring Proclamation 1081, 23 Sep 1972
media_credit: Presidential Museum and Library of the Philippines
text_headline: MARCOS DECLARES MARTIAL LAW
text_description: Marcos signs Proclamation No. 1081, placing the Philippines under martial law, citing the Communist insurgency, Muslim separatism, and the Sep 22 alleged ambush on Defense Secretary Juan Ponce Enrile as reasons. He then proceeds to incarcerate his political enemies, including Benigno Aquino Jr, and suspected communists. He controlled and shut down all media outlets except for the Philippines Daily Express, one television station (channel 9), and one radio station (Kanlaon Broadcasting).
The Ramon Magsaysay Awards, Asia’s Nobel Prize, is established.
Humans use stone flake tools in Tabon Cave at Lipuun Point in Palawan.

text_headline: Isabeline Gothic spreads in Spain. Named after Queen Isabela, this is the Spanish variation on the Gothic.
text_description: Isabeline Gothic spreads in Spain. Named after Queen Isabela, this is the Spanish variation on the Gothic.

text_headline: St. Peter’s Basilica on Vatican Hill, Rome is inaugurated.
text_description: St. Peter’s Basilica on Vatican Hill, Rome is inaugurated.

text_headline: During the Byzantine era, domed churches with mosaic interior decorations proliferate.
text_description: During the Byzantine era, domed churches with mosaic interior decorations proliferate.

text_headline: Manila is created as a diocese of the Catholic Church but does not have a resident bishop until 1581.
text_description: Manila is created as a diocese of the Catholic Church but does not have a resident bishop until 1581.

text_headline: Romanesque monasteries and churches, characterized by solidity and the use of Roman arch for structural strength, spreads throughout Europe.
text_description: Romanesque monasteries and churches, characterized by solidity and the use of Roman arch for structural strength, spreads throughout Europe.

text_headline: A flourishing trade between the Philippines and China brings numerous tradeware, especially Chinese porcelain and stoneware, to the Philippines.
text_description: A flourishing trade between the Philippines and China brings numerous tradeware, especially Chinese porcelain and stoneware, to the Philippines. These were used for dowries and rituals, and buried with the deceased.

text_headline: King Ferdinand (1452-1516) and Queen Isabela (1451-1504) wrest southern Spain from the Moors and consolidate the Kingdom of Castille and Aragon to create a united Spain.
text_description: King Ferdinand (1452-1516) and Queen Isabela (1451-1504) wrest southern Spain from the Moors and consolidate the Kingdom of Castille and Aragon to create a united Spain.

text_headline: Columbus lands in the Caribbean.
text_description: Columbus lands in the Caribbean. His expedition is funded by Queen Isabela of Spain.

text_headline: In Cebu, Magellan and Rajah Humabon make a blood compact.
text_description: In Cebu, Magellan and Rajah Humabon make a blood compact. Humabon and his wife are later baptized as Carlos and Juana. Magellan erects a cross, said to be encased in a larger tindalo cross inside a 19th century kiosk of cut coral.

text_headline: After two failed expeditions to retrace Magellan’s journey to the Philippines, Ruy López de Villalobos (ca 1500-1544) arrives at Samar and Leyte
text_description: After two failed expeditions to retrace Magellan’s journey to the Philippines, Ruy López de Villalobos (ca 1500-1544) arrives at Samar and Leyte, naming them Las Islas Filipinas, after crown prince Felipe II (1527-1598), son of Carlos I of Spain (r. 1500-1558).

text_headline: The Portuguese and their allies attack Panglao Strait in Bohol.
text_description: The Portuguese and their allies attack Panglao Strait in Bohol. The Boholanos flee to Dapitan, northern Mindanao.

text_headline: Adelantado Miguel Lopez de Legazpi (r. 1565-1572), commanding four ships, arrives in the Philippines
text_description: Adelantado Miguel Lopez de Legazpi (r. 1565-1572), commanding four ships, arrives in the Philippines, with his chief navigator, Fr. Andrés de Urdaneta, OSA (1498-1568). He later claims Cebu for Spain.

text_headline: Urdaneta discovers the tornaviaje, the west to east current above the Philippines at about 30 degrees latitude, that can bring ships back to Mexico.
text_description: Urdaneta discovers the tornaviaje, the west to east current above the Philippines at about 30 degrees latitude, that can bring ships back to Mexico. He brings a ship loaded with spices to Mexico, its value enough to pay for the cost of Legazpi’s expedition. The Manila-Mexico galleon trade begins.

text_headline: The Philippines is placed under the Vice-Royalty of Mexico.
text_description: The Philippines is placed under the Vice-Royalty of Mexico. The Spanish colonial era begins.

text_headline: Gothic architecture, characterized by height, lightness, and the use of strained glass, originates in France but spreads throughout Europe
text_description: Gothic architecture, characterized by height, lightness, and the use of strained glass, originates in France but spreads throughout Europe, giving rise to regional variations.

text_headline: Spaniards lay siege to the kuta or stronghold of Rajah Sulayman (1558-1575) at the mouth of the Pasig and later occupy it.
text_description: Spaniards lay siege to the kuta or stronghold of Rajah Sulayman (1558-1575) at the mouth of the Pasig and later occupy it.

text_headline: The city of Manila is established by Legazpi on Sulayman’s kuta.
text_description: The city of Manila is established by Legazpi on Sulayman’s kuta.

text_headline: Philip II issues the Leyes de las Indias (Laws of the Indies).
text_description: Philip II issues the Leyes de las Indias (Laws of the Indies), a codification and amplification of previous laws and decrees concerning the establishment of presidios or military towns and pueblos or civilian towns.

text_headline: The Chinese Limahong (d. 1575) attacks Manila but is repelled.
text_description: The Chinese Limahong (d. 1575) attacks Manila but is repelled. He launches a second attack in December but is repulsed by Salcedo.

text_headline: Gov-Gen Lavesares revokes the privileges promised by Legazpi to Rajahs Lakandula and Sulayman.
text_description: Gov-Gen Lavesares revokes the privileges promised by Legazpi to Rajahs Lakandula and Sulayman. The two stage a revolt which is quelled by the Spanish.

text_headline: Capt Pedro de San Lucar establishes Ciudad de Nueva Caceres (later Naga).
text_description: Capt Pedro de San Lucar establishes Ciudad de Nueva Caceres (later Naga).

text_headline: The Franciscans arrive in the Philippines.
text_description: The Franciscans arrive in the Philippines.

text_headline: Felipe II becomes king of Portugal; Portuguese harassment of the Philippines ends.
text_description: Felipe II becomes king of Portugal; Portuguese harassment of the Philippines ends.

text_headline: The Church Il Gesù, Rome, which was in a transition style between Renaissance and Baroque, is inaugurated.
text_description: The Church Il Gesù, Rome, which was in a transition style between Renaissance and Baroque, is inaugurated. Il Gesù is considered as the prototype Baroque church and the expression of an ideal church by the Council of Trent. It set the pattern for many churches worldwide.

text_headline: El Escorial Palace is completed by Juan de Herrera (1530-1597).
text_description: El Escorial Palace is completed by Juan de Herrera (1530-1597). With El Escorial, the Italinate Renaissance style is brought to Spain.

text_headline: Domingo de Salazar, OP (1579-1594) arrives to take his position as bishop of Manila.
text_description: Domingo de Salazar, OP (1579-1594) arrives to take his position as bishop of Manila. Three Jesuits, including Antonio Sedeño (1535-1595), arrive in Manila with Bp Salazar.

text_headline: Fire destroys Manila, caused by unattended candles around the catafulque of Gov. Gonzalo Ronquillo (r. 1580-1583).
text_description: Fire destroys Manila, caused by unattended candles around the catafulque of Gov. Gonzalo Ronquillo (r. 1580-1583).

text_headline: Bp. Salazar calls for a synod in Manila to address issues of slavery, oppression, and Spain’s right to colonize the Philippines.
text_description: Bp. Salazar calls for a synod in Manila to address issues of slavery, oppression, and Spain’s right to colonize the Philippines.

text_headline: Kapampangan leaders, responding to abuses by encomenderos, plan to attack Intramuros but are foiled because the plot is divulged by a Filipina to her Spanish husband.
text_description: Kapampangan leaders, responding to abuses by encomenderos, plan to attack Intramuros but are foiled because the plot is divulged by a Filipina to her Spanish husband. This is dubbed the First Pampanga Revolt.

text_headline: The Dominicans arrive in the Philippines
text_description: The Dominicans arrive in the Philippines

text_headline: Philip II authorizes setting up the Colegio de Santa Potenciana for orphan daughters of military personnel.
text_description: Philip II authorizes setting up the Colegio de Santa Potenciana for orphan daughters of military personnel.

text_headline: Franciscans cede the town of Taytay and Antipolo to the Jesuits.
text_description: Franciscans cede the town of Taytay and Antipolo to the Jesuits. Pedro Chirino SJ (1558-1635) transfers the townsite of Taytay from the lakeshore to a nearby hill.

text_headline: Chirino arrives in Tigbauan, Iloilo and founds a school, said to be the first Jesuit school in the Visayas.
text_description: Chirino arrives in Tigbauan, Iloilo and founds a school, said to be the first Jesuit school in the Visayas.

text_headline: Spanish troops are sent to Zamboanga.
text_description: Spanish troops are sent to Zamboanga.

text_headline: Jesuits acquire an hacienda at Marikina for the Colegio de San Ignacio.
text_description: Jesuits acquire an hacienda at Marikina for the Colegio de San Ignacio.

text_headline: The Philippines is divided into areas of evangelization to which are assigned specific religious orders.
text_description: The Philippines is divided into areas of evangelization to which are assigned specific religious orders.

text_headline: The Colegio de Manila or Colegio de San Ignacio opens in Intramuros.
text_description: The Colegio de Manila or Colegio de San Ignacio opens in Intramuros.

text_headline: The Magalat Revolt in Cagayan Valley erupts.
text_description: The Magalat Revolt in Cagayan Valley erupts. Together with his brothers, Magalat successfully controls the countryside. Spanish and Filipino troops under Pedro Chaves quell the revolt.

text_headline: Valerio de Ledesma, SJ (1556-1639) founds a mission in Butuan, Mindanao.
text_description: Valerio de Ledesma, SJ (1556-1639) founds a mission in Butuan, Mindanao. He had arrived as a chaplain of the Spanish ships.

text_headline: A devastating earthquake hits Manila.
text_description: A devastating earthquake hits Manila.

text_headline: Augustinians establish the visita of Sialo or Siaro dependent on Santo Niño, Cebu.
text_description: Augustinians establish the visita of Sialo or Siaro dependent on Santo Niño, Cebu. This is the beginning of the town of Carcar, Cebu.

text_headline: Another devastating earthquake destroys Manila structures.
text_description: Another devastating earthquake destroys Manila structures.

text_headline: Dutch VOC or East Indies Company launches attacks on the Philippines in an effort to wrest the Oriental trade from Spain.
text_description: Dutch VOC or East Indies Company launches attacks on the Philippines in an effort to wrest the Oriental trade from Spain.

text_headline: In the battle between the Dutch ship Mauritius and the Spanish ship San Diego, the latter sinks.
text_description: In the battle between the Dutch ship Mauritius and the Spanish ship San Diego, the latter sinks. Van Noort and his ships retreat.

text_headline: The Colegio de San Ildefonso in Cebu is inaugurated.
text_description: The Colegio de San Ildefonso in Cebu is inaugurated.

text_headline: Colegio de San Jose is inaugurated.
text_description: Colegio de San Jose is inaugurated.

text_headline: A military detachment is set up in port of Iloilo.
text_description: A military detachment is set up in port of Iloilo, which is a half-way point for provisioning military installations in Mindanao.

text_headline: The Augustinian Recollects arrive in Manila.
text_description: The Augustinian Recollects arrive in Manila.

text_headline: Pascual de Acuña, SJ (1573-1643), chaplain of the Spanish armada, preaches in Dapitan and baptizes more than 200 persons
text_description: Pascual de Acuña, SJ (1573-1643), chaplain of the Spanish armada, preaches in Dapitan and baptizes more than 200 persons

text_headline: Japanese Christians fleeing the Tokugawa persecution arrive in Manila.
text_description: Japanese Christians fleeing the Tokugawa persecution arrive in Manila, including Daimyo (Lord) Justo Takayama Ukon (1552-1615) as head, his family, and Maria Nayto, who founded a beaterio in Miyako (Kyoto), and her beatas. The Japanese are assigned to San Miguel and later to Dilao in Paco.

text_headline: Iloilo called La Punta is made a visita under Arevalo after being under Otong (Oton).
text_description: Iloilo called La Punta is made a visita under Arevalo after being under Otong (Oton).

text_headline: Eastern Mindanao is ceded to the Recollects by the Jesuits.
text_description: Eastern Mindanao is ceded to the Recollects by the Jesuits.

text_headline: Colegio de Manila is raised to university status by Gregory XV, renamed Universidad de San Ignacio.
text_description: Colegio de Manila is raised to university status by Gregory XV, renamed Universidad de San Ignacio.

text_headline: The period of High Roman Baroque begins and lasts until 1667.
text_description: The period of High Roman Baroque begins and lasts until 1667.

text_headline: Monte de Piedad bank opens offices in the Colegio de Santa Isabel.
text_description: Monte de Piedad bank opens offices in the Colegio de Santa Isabel.

text_headline: Gov. Hurtado de Corcuera (r. 1635-1644) orders the Chinese and Spanish traders to move to La Punta in Molo.
text_description: Gov. Hurtado de Corcuera (r. 1635-1644) orders the Chinese and Spanish traders to move to La Punta in Molo.

text_headline: Louis XIV reigns until 1715. During his reign, the construction of the Versailles in the Baroque style commences.
text_description: Louis XIV reigns until 1715. During his reign, the construction of the Versailles in the Baroque style commences.

text_headline: A devastating earthquake destroys Manila.
text_description: A devastating earthquake destroys Manila.

text_headline: The Zambales Revolt is triggered by a protest against tribute.
text_description: The Zambales Revolt is triggered by a protest against tribute.

text_headline: The Pampanga Revolt is led by a babaylan against the Spanish because of the burdens of colonial rule.
text_description: The Pampanga Revolt is led by a babaylan against the Spanish because of the burdens of colonial rule.

text_headline: Rococo begins in France.
text_description: Rococo begins in France. It is characterized by the use of pastels rather than primaries, asymmetry and thinner and lighter decorations than Baroque.

text_headline: The Churiguerra family (active until Ca 1720) promotes an intricate, exagerrated form of surface decoration, using the solomonic column and the estipite.
text_description: The Churiguerra family (active until Ca 1720) promotes an intricate, exagerrated form of surface decoration, using the solomonic column and the estipite. The Churiguerresque style becomes popular in Mexico, but has limited expression in the Philippines. The altar of the Church of San Jacinto in Tuguegarao is a rare example of the use of the Churrigueresque estipite.

text_headline: Andres Malong proclaims himself “king of Pangasinan” and sets up his own government with a following of 11,000 persons.
text_description: Andres Malong proclaims himself “king of Pangasinan” and sets up his own government with a following of 11,000 persons.

text_headline: Colegio de Santa Catalina, run by female Dominican tertiaries, is established.
text_description: Colegio de Santa Catalina, run by female Dominican tertiaries, is established.

text_headline: Devastating earthquake hits Manila and neighboring provinces.
text_description: Devastating earthquake hits Manila and neighboring provinces.

text_headline: Revivalist Architecture in Europe introduces the Neoclassical style, typified by St. Paul Cathedral by Christopher Wren in London.
text_description: Revivalist Architecture in Europe introduces the Neoclassical style, typified by St. Paul Cathedral by Christopher Wren in London. Revivalist refers to a backward referential style of architecture that replaces the Baroque from the 18th century onward.

text_headline: Mughal Empire permits the British East India Company to trade in India duty free.
text_description: Mughal Empire permits the British East India Company to trade in India duty free. Mughal infuence is introduced to British art and architecture.

text_headline: Neoclassicism spreads in popularity throughout Europe.
text_description: Neoclassicism spreads in popularity throughout Europe. Later it will reach the European colonies.

text_headline: The eruption of Mt. Banahaw causes the destruction of Sariaya on its slopes, and results in the transfer of the town to its present site.
text_description: The eruption of Mt. Banahaw causes the destruction of Sariaya on its slopes, and results in the transfer of the town to its present site.

text_headline: Colegio de Santa Rosa in Intramuros is established by Madre Paula de Santisima Trinidad (1713-1782).
text_description: Colegio de Santa Rosa in Intramuros is established by Madre Paula de Santisima Trinidad (1713-1782).

text_headline: The Industrial Revolution in Europe begins in England with the invention of the steam engine and the establishment of large factories.
text_description: The Industrial Revolution in Europe begins in England with the invention of the steam engine and the establishment of large factories. The Industrial Revolution introduces innovative technologies for construction, such as cast iron columns and piers and zinc and galvanized iron roofing.

text_headline: The eruption of Taal volcano for over 200 days destroys Lipa, Sala, Tanuan, and Talisay.
text_description: The eruption of Taal volcano for over 200 days destroys Lipa, Sala, Tanuan, and Talisay. Taal transfers yet again to even higher ground.

text_headline: Silay, Negros Occidental is established as a town.
text_description: Silay, Negros Occidental is established as a town.

text_headline: The Seven Years War between France, with ally Spain, and England comes to an end.
text_description: The Seven Years War between France, with ally Spain, and England comes to an end.

text_headline: Manila falls to the British after the bombardment of its southern flank.
text_description: Manila falls to the British after the bombardment of its southern flank. Before Manila falls, Simon de Anda travels north and heads the government in exile at Bacolor, Pampanga, from Oct 1762 to Feb 1764, by appointment of the Real Audiencia.

text_headline: As a result of the British occupation which weakens the Spanish military, revolts erupt, including those of Diego Silang in Ilocos, Palaris in Pangasinan.
text_description: As a result of the British occupation which weakens the Spanish military, revolts erupt, including those of Diego Silang in Ilocos, Palaris in Pangasinan.

text_headline: The British leave the Philippines; the turnover ceremony takes place in front of Santa Cruz church outside Intramuros.
text_description: The British leave the Philippines; the turnover ceremony takes place in front of Santa Cruz church outside Intramuros. Anda hands over governorship to Francisco Xavier de la Torre (r. 1764-1765).

text_headline: Southern raiders make a bold move to extend their sphere by attacking coastal towns in Manila Bay and Mariveles.
text_description: Southern raiders make a bold move to extend their sphere by attacking coastal towns in Manila Bay and Mariveles.

text_headline: Real Sociedad Economica de los Amigos del Pais de Filipinas is established by businessmen who want to modernize the Philippine economy.
text_description: Real Sociedad Economica de los Amigos del Pais de Filipinas is established by businessmen who want to modernize the Philippine economy. It sponsors scientific expeditions, gives scholarships, and sends new technology to the Philippines.

text_headline: Gov-Gen Basco, who supports the objectives of Amigos del Pais, introduces tobacco as a cash export crop in Luzon, especially in the Ilocos.
text_description: Gov-Gen Basco, who supports the objectives of Amigos del Pais, introduces tobacco as a cash export crop in Luzon, especially in the Ilocos.

text_headline: The French Revolution ends the royal extravagance associated with Baroque and Rococo.
text_description: The French Revolution ends the royal extravagance associated with Baroque and Rococo.

text_headline: A scientific expedition to the Philippines and the Pacific, sponsored by the Spanish monarch is headed by Alessandro Malaspina (1754-1810).
text_description: A scientific expedition to the Philippines and the Pacific, sponsored by the Spanish monarch is headed by Alessandro Malaspina (1754-1810).

text_headline: Neogothic or Gothic Revival (late 18th Cent – Early 20th In Europe) style gains popularity.
text_description: Neogothic or Gothic Revival (late 18th Cent – Early 20th In Europe) style gains popularity, spreads to USA and Canada, and is used for government buildings.

text_headline: Mexico begins a revolution of independence from Spain led by a Catholic mestizo priest, Miguel Hidalgo de Costilla.
text_description: Mexico begins a revolution of independence from Spain led by a Catholic mestizo priest, Miguel Hidalgo de Costilla.

text_headline: The Cadiz constitution is promulgated in the Philippines.
text_description: The Cadiz constitution is promulgated in the Philippines.

text_headline: Because of the ongoing Mexican revolution of independence, the last of the galleons sails out of Mexico; this ends the galleon trade.
text_description: Because of the ongoing Mexican revolution of independence, the last of the galleons sails out of Mexico; this ends the galleon trade.

text_headline: Because of Mexico’s independence, the Philippines is now ruled directly from Madrid.
text_description: Because of Mexico’s independence, the Philippines is now ruled directly from Madrid.

text_headline: The first steam railway is built in Britain
text_description: The first steam railway is built in Britain

text_headline: Jesuits are expelled from the Philippines after the royal decree arrives in Manila.
text_description: Jesuits are expelled from the Philippines after the royal decree arrives in Manila. Jesuit missions in Mindanao and Bohol are turned over to the Recollects; Samar and Leyte to the Augustinians, later to the Franciscans. Jesuit properties are sequestered and inventoried worldwide. The expulsion from the realms of the Bourbons of Portugal, France, and Spain is the first step in the dissolution of the Jesuits. The Bourbons achieve their goal in 1773, when Pope Clement XIV (r. 1769-1774) suppresses the order.

text_headline: Nicolas Loney, British vice-consul, introduces steam driven sugar mills, revolutionizing sugar production.
text_description: Nicolas Loney, British vice-consul, introduces steam driven sugar mills, revolutionizing sugar production. As a result of Loney’s innovation, sugar plantations and mills in Iloilo and Negros expand and proliferate. This export cash crop will give rise to the sugar barons of Iloilo and Negros Occidental.

text_headline: Frenchman and entrepreneur Yves Leopold Germain Gaston introduces the horno economico in Negros to produce raw sugar or muscovado more efficiently.
text_description: Frenchman and entrepreneur Yves Leopold Germain Gaston introduces the horno economico in Negros to produce raw sugar or muscovado more efficiently. The economic upturn of Silay, Negros Occidental begins.

text_headline: An earthquake hits Iloilo.
text_description: An earthquake hits Iloilo.

text_headline: The Recollects establish the Mision de San Pedro in Davao.
text_description: The Recollects establish the Mision de San Pedro in Davao.

text_headline: A devastating earthquake hits Manila and environs.
text_description: A devastating earthquake hits Manila and environs.

text_headline: Jesuits return to the Philippines and are missioned to Mindanao.
text_description: Jesuits return to the Philippines and are missioned to Mindanao

text_headline: The mision de San Pedro in Davao is raised to a parish.
text_description: The mision de San Pedro in Davao is raised to a parish.

text_headline: A devastating earthquake hits Manila.
text_description: A devastating earthquake hits Manila.

text_headline: Isabela II (1830-1904) gives UST the power to direct and supervise all schools in the Philippines.
text_description: Isabela II (1830-1904) gives UST the power to direct and supervise all schools in the Philippines; its rector becomes ex-officio head of secondary and higher eduction.

text_headline: Augustinians take charge of La Paz, Iloilo.
text_description: Augustinians take charge of La Paz, Iloilo.

text_headline: Seminario de San Vicente in Iloilo is established and opens classes at the bishop’s residence.
text_description: Seminario de San Vicente in Iloilo is established and opens classes at the bishop’s residence.

text_headline: Gov-Gen Narciso Claveria (in office 1844-1849) attacks and occupies Jolo.
text_description: Gov-Gen Narciso Claveria (in office 1844-1849) attacks and occupies Jolo.

text_headline: In Tamontaka, Cotabato, the Jesuits establish a reduction, with a school, for the Tiruray who were slaves of the Maguindanao.
text_description: In Tamontaka, Cotabato, the Jesuits establish a reduction, with a school, for the Tiruray who were slaves of the Maguindanao.

text_headline: After forging an agreement with the Sulu Sultanate, the Spanish build a settlement in Jolo, protected by walls and two auxiliary forts.
text_description: After forging an agreement with the Sulu Sultanate, the Spanish build a settlement in Jolo, protected by walls and two auxiliary forts.The Spanish also build a watchtower at Jolo’s harbor.

text_headline: The Jesuits, who had arrived earlier as military chaplains after the Spanish conquest of Jolo in 1872, establish a mission.
text_description: The Jesuits, who had arrived earlier as military chaplains after the Spanish conquest of Jolo in 1872, establish a mission.

text_headline: Cable service to Hong Kong is established with the cable exiting the Philippines at Bolinao, Pangasinan.
text_description: Cable service to Hong Kong is established with the cable exiting the Philippines at Bolinao, Pangasinan. It is through this cable that Aguinaldo will get in touch with the Katipunan, while on exile in Hong Kong.

text_headline: Jesuits open Escuela Normal de San Francisco Xavier.
text_description: Jesuits open Escuela Normal de San Francisco Xavier for the training of maestros and maestras for the primary school system set up by the Spanish government.

text_headline: Gustave Eiffel (1832-1923) builds a steel tower in Paris for an international exposition that projects France as an industrializing country.
text_description: Gustave Eiffel (1832-1923) builds a steel tower in Paris for an international exposition that projects France as an industrializing country. Intended as a temporary structure, the tower remains after the exposition.

text_headline: Art Noveau makes its first appearance in Paris.
text_description: Art Noveau makes its first appearance in Paris. It is a total style that covers architecture, painting and crafts like textile, fashion design, furniture, signage and typography. It is inspired by nature, especially sinuous vines, flowers, and female beauty.

text_headline: Queen Regent of Spain Maria Cristina (1858-1929) raises Iloilo to the status of a city.
text_description: Queen Regent of Spain Maria Cristina (1858-1929) raises Iloilo to the status of a city.

text_headline: The Assumption sisters arrive at the invitation of Queen Regent Maria Cristina of Spain.
text_description: The Assumption sisters arrive at the invitation of Queen Regent Maria Cristina of Spain to establish a teacher training school for women to complement the Jesuits’ training school for male teachers.

text_headline: The Beaux Arts, a movement in Neoclassicim
text_description: The Beaux Arts, a movement in Neoclassicim, that applies the tenets of the style in buildings and urban planning takes hold in France and spreads to Europe and the United States, where its advocate is Daniel Hudson Burnham.

text_headline: Benedictines take over administration of Caraga from the Jesuits.
text_description: Benedictines take over administration of Caraga from the Jesuits. They are sent by the Spanish crown to open agricultural settlements in Mindanao.

text_headline: By royal decree, Iloilo is given the privilege to have its coat of arms and the title “la muy leal y noble ciudad de Iloilo.
text_description: By royal decree, Iloilo is given the privilege to have its coat of arms and the title “la muy leal y noble ciudad de Iloilo.

text_headline: Radio Theater presents Fred Waring’s Pennsylvanian Syncopation, the first talkie.
text_description: Radio Theater presents Fred Waring’s Pennsylvanian Syncopation, the first talkie.

text_headline: The Communist Party of the Philippines is established in response to the mounting protests from many labor groups.
text_description: The Communist Party of the Philippines is established in response to the mounting protests from many labor groups. These social issues will inspire many films like Tayug: Ang Bayang Api (1947) and Huk sa Bagong Pamumuhay (1953).

text_headline: The Lumiere brothers hold the first film screening to a paying public at Salon Indien du Grand Café, Paris.
text_description: The Lumiere brothers hold the first film screening to a paying public at Salon Indien du Grand Café, Paris.

text_headline: Edison patents his Kinetoscope.
text_description: Edison patents his Kinetoscope.

text_headline: The US declares war on Spain.
text_description: The US declares war on Spain. This will bring US forces to the Philippines, then still a Spanish colony.

text_headline: The first nickelodeon theater opens in Pennsylvania, USA.
text_description: The first nickelodeon theater opens in Pennsylvania, USA.

text_headline: Paramount Pictures is founded.
text_description: Paramount Pictures is founded; it will be followed by other film production companies such as Universal Pictures, Warner Bros, Walt Disney Pictures, and Columbia. This paves the way for the “studio system” which will also influence film production in the Philippines.

text_headline: D. W. Griffith’s The Birth of a Nation is shown.
text_description: D. W. Griffith’s The Birth of a Nation is shown. Despite its racist overtones, the film becomes a landmark in cinema history for its innovative filmmaking techniques such as dramatic close-ups and other camera and editing techniques.

text_headline: The Venice Film Festival is founded.
text_description: The Venice Film Festival is founded.

media_caption: Outer walls of Fort Pilar
text_headline: Americans seize Zamboanga from the Spanish.
text_description: Americans seize Zamboanga from the Spanish. Petite Barracks is established outside Fort Pilar at the site of Santa Barbara.

text_headline: The Metro Manila Development Administration (MMDA) launches Metro Guwapo: Looking Forward to a Good-looking Manila.
text_description: The Metro Manila Development Administration (MMDA) launches Metro Guwapo: Looking Forward to a Good-looking Manila.

media_caption: University of the Philippines along Padre Faura Street, Manila
media_credit: Philippine Picture Post Cards: 1900-1920 by Jonathan Best, The Bookmark, Inc, 1994
text_headline: The University of the Philippines, the first secular university, is established.
text_description: The University of the Philippines, the first secular university, opens which includes the formation of the Escuela de Bellas Artes or School of Fine Arts in 1909 led by Rafael Enriquez as Director until 1925. An agent of Americanization, it will later breed many leading nationalist artists and writers. It will produce major visual artists and groups, lead in higher music education, and establish the first academic film program in the country and produce outstanding film artists.

text_headline: Modernist architecture appears in Europe and later in the US.
text_description: Modernist architecture appears in Europe and later in the US. Its tenets of functionality, clarity of form over ornament, and minimalism will influence Philippine architecture after World War II.

text_headline: The Jones Law
text_description: The Jones Law, aka the Philippine Autonomy Act, which replaces Philippine Organic Act of 1902 and provides for a more autonomous Philippine government, is passed by the US Congress. It creates the first fully elected Philippine legislature.

media_caption: Negros Occidental Capitol in Bacolod City, 2013
text_headline: Negros Occidental declares independence from Spain; Bacolod is made the capital.
text_description: Negros Occidental declares independence from Spain; Bacolod is made the capital.

text_headline: The Cannes Film Festival is founded.
text_description: The Cannes Film Festival is founded. The Cannes, along with Venice and Berlin Film Festivals, will later on recognize various Filipino films and artists.

text_headline: The Mutual Defense Treaty with the US is signed.
text_description: The Mutual Defense Treaty with the US is signed.

text_headline: Sharif Kabungsuan from Johore Malacca arrives in Mindanao after the fall of Malaca to Dutch imperialists.
text_description: Sharif Kabungsuan from Johore Malacca arrives in Mindanao after the fall of Malaca to Dutch imperialists.

text_headline: The Philippines becomes part of the vice-royalty of Mexico.
text_description: The Philippines becomes part of the vice-royalty of Mexico, beginning the era of the galleon trade.

text_headline: Claudio Monteverdi (1567-1643) composes La Fabola d’Orfeo (considered the first opera).
text_description: Claudio Monteverdi (1567-1643) composes La Fabola d’Orfeo (considered the first opera).

text_headline: Jugar con Fuego
text_description: Jugar con Fuego, a Spanish zarzuela by librettist Ventura de la Vega and composer Francisco Asenjo Barbieri, premieres in Madrid. Considered the first zarzuela, it represents the affirmation of Spanish identity via-a-vis the French opéra comique.

media_caption: Gen Douglas MacArthur returning to the Philippines, 20 Oct 1944
media_credit: US National Archives and Records Administration
text_headline: General Douglas MacArthur arrives in Leyte.
text_description: General Douglas MacArthur arrives in Leyte.

media_caption: Diosdado Lorenzo, Atrocities in Paco
text_headline: The US forces bomb out the Japanese Imperial forces in the Battle of Manila.
text_description: The US forces bomb out the Japanese Imperial forces in the Battle of Manila. It ends the Japanese Occupation of the Philippines.

text_headline: Giovanni Pierluigi da Palestrina (ca 1525-1594) composes vocal polyphonic music for the Tridentine mass.
text_description: Giovanni Pierluigi da Palestrina (ca 1525-1594) composes vocal polyphonic music for the Tridentine mass.

text_headline: Western Europe develops the madrigal genre.
text_description: Western Europe develops the madrigal genre.

text_headline: Arab traders arrive in the Sulu archipelago and Jolo, starting the process of Islamization.
text_description: Arab traders arrive in the Sulu archipelago and Jolo, starting the process of Islamization. Between 1450 and 1500, the Sultanates of Maguindanao, Lanao and Sulu, and other parts of the Philippines are established.

text_headline: An earthquake hits Bohol and Cebu as the Inabanga fault and its branches move.
text_description: A magnitude 7.2 earthquake hits Bohol and Cebu as the Inabanga fault and its branches move. Earth is uplifted by almost two meters inland and by a meter at the Maribojoc shore.

text_headline: Since the 1990s, there is an active participation by Filipino artists in international biennales
text_description: Since the 1990s, there is an active participation by Filipino artists in international biennales such as Havana, Melbourne, Paris, Sydney, Tokyo, Yokohama, and Documenta, as official Philippine representatives or as artists working out from their present countries of residence. This continues with the escalating importance of Asia-based platforms such as those in Dhaka, Gwangju, Jakarta, Shanghai, Singapore, and Taipei.

text_headline: Supreme Court voids the conferment of National Artist Award on Caparas (along with architect Francisco Mañosa, fashion designer Jose “Pitoy” Moreno, and theater artist Cecile Guidote-Alvarez).
text_description: Supreme Court voids the conferment of National Artist Award on Caparas (along with architect Francisco Mañosa, fashion designer Jose “Pitoy” Moreno, and theater artist Cecile Guidote-Alvarez).

text_headline: Senior High School (K-11 and 12) is added to Basic Education.
text_description: Senior High School (K-11 and 12) is added to Basic Education.

text_headline: The music streaming program Spotify becomes available in the Philippines, as well as paid downloads of Filipino music in Apple’s iTunes.
text_description: The music streaming program Spotify becomes available in the Philippines, as well as paid downloads of Filipino music in Apple’s iTunes.

media_caption: Sheik Karimul Makdum Mosque, in Simunul, Tawi-Tawi, known as the oldest mosque in the country, 2010
text_description: Muslim Arabs arrive at the Sulu Archipelago. Among them is Sheik Karim-ul Makdum who builds a mosque at Tubig Indangan, Simunul, Tawi-Tawi—the oldest surviving mosque in the Philippines. He is followed by Abubakar who comes in 1450.

text_headline: US Navy Commodore George Dewey destroys Spanish troop in the Battle of Manila Bay, ending Spanish rule in the Philippines
text_description: US Navy Commodore George Dewey destroys Spanish troop in the Battle of Manila Bay, ending Spanish rule in the Philippines

text_headline: The Department of Science and Technology begins implementation of the nationwide free WiFi project.
text_description: The Department of Science and Technology begins implementation of the nationwide free WiFi project.
The Islamic religion is established by 600 AD in the Middle East.

text_headline: The Laguna Copperplate is inscribed
text_description: The Laguna Copperplate is inscribed, evincing the existence of cultural ties between the precolonial Tagalog and other Asian civilizations.

text_headline: The Gutenberg Bible becomes the first book printed using the movable type printing press, ushering in the age of the printed book in the West.
text_description: The Gutenberg Bible becomes the first book printed using the movable type printing press, ushering in the age of the printed book in the West. In the Philippines, the first book will be printed in 1593.

text_headline: Trade with neighboring islands flourishes.
text_description: Trade with neighboring islands flourishes.

text_headline: Radio and TV cover live the hostage-taking incident at Luneta that takes the lives of eight Hong Kong tourists and the hostage taker.
text_description: Radio and TV cover live the hostage-taking incident at Luneta that takes the lives of eight Hong Kong tourists and the hostage taker.

text_headline: RA 10066 or the National Cultural Heritage Act of 2009
text_description: RA 10066 or the National Cultural Heritage Act of 2009, prompting cultural institutions to preserve and restore heritage structures such as the Metropolitan Theater of Manila, is enacted.

text_headline: Former President Joseph Estrada is convicted of plunder, the first ever in the history of the Philippines.
text_description: Former President Joseph Estrada is convicted of plunder, the first ever in the history of the Philippines.

text_headline: In preparation for the K-12 transition in Basic Education, the Department of Education begins teaching a new integrated subject MAPEH (Music, Arts, Physical Education, and Health).
text_description: In preparation for the K-12 transition in Basic Education, the Department of Education begins teaching a new integrated subject MAPEH (Music, Arts, Physical Education, and Health).

text_headline: President Arroyo confers the National Artist award for Visual Arts and Film on Carlo Caparas (b. 1948) and three others without going through the process, creating controversy.
text_description: President Arroyo confers the National Artist award for Visual Arts and Film on Carlo Caparas (b. 1948) and three others without going through the process, creating controversy. Some national artists file a protest with the Supreme Court.

text_headline: Benigno Simeon C Aquino III is inaugurated President.
text_description: Benigno Simeon C. Aquino III is inaugurated President. His term ends in 2016.

media_caption: Imelda Marcos, center, with the winner and candidates of Miss Universe 1974
text_description: The Miss Universe contest is held for the first time in Manila in the Folk Arts Theater.

media_caption: Corazon Aquino taking her oath as the 11th President of the Republic of the Philippines, 24 Feb 1986, Club Filipino, San Juan City
media_credit: (Photo by Robin Moyer, Bayan Ko! Images of the Philippine Revolt. Veritas Publications & Communications, Inc, 1986.)
text_description: Corazon C Aquino is inaugurated President. At noon, Marcos also takes his oath as President at Malacañan Palace. At 9:52 pm, DZRH announces that the Marcoses have fled the country to Hawaii.

media_caption: Scene from the film adaptation of Home along da Riles, 1993
text_description: The first commercial TV station, DZAQ-TV Channel 3 of Alto Broadcasting System, opens in Manila. TV will produce popular programs which will have film versions, like John en Marsha and Home Along da Riles.

text_headline: The Academy Awards (“Oscars”) is established by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences (AMPAS).
text_description: The Academy Awards (“Oscars”) is established by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences (AMPAS). This will inspire the formation of the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS).

media_caption: Main maritime roads during the Song and Yuan Dynasties (de Monbrison and Alvina 2013)
text_headline: Long distance trade develops with Chinese junks and Bornean parao bringing trade goods such as porcelain, ironware, silk threads, Javanese batik, and fine-woven mats.
text_description: Long distance trade develops with Chinese junks and Bornean parao bringing trade goods such as porcelain, ironware, silk threads, Javanese batik, and fine-woven mats.

media_caption: Bangle with foliate Romano-Byzantine design in deep relief from Butuan, ca 800-1300 CE
text_headline: Bangle with foliate Romano-Byzantine design in deep relief
text_description: Butuan becomes a major trading port in the 10th to the 12th century supplying gold, wax, and slaves.

media_caption: Lino Brocka and Hilda Koronel on the set of Hilda, ca 1971
media_credit: Lino Brocka: The Artist and His Times  edited by  Mario A. Hernando. Sentrong Pangkultura ng Pilipinas, 1993.
text_description: Framed by a Constitutional convention of which Lino Brocka is a part, the 1987 Philippine Constitution is later approved by a referendum and promulgated. It contains Brocka’s article on “freedom of expression.”
The Philippines becomes a founding member of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations or ASEAN, which will sponsor artistic and literary exchange in the region.

media_caption: Chief Justice Renato Corona during his impeachment trial, 2011, aired on national television
media_credit: The Honor of the Senate, 44 Days of an Impeachment Trial by Nicolas B. Pichay. The Senate of the Republic of the Philippines, 2012.
text_headline: Supreme Court Chief Justice Renato Corona is impeached by the Senate for failure to publicly disclose his statement of assets and liabilities.
text_description: Supreme Court Chief Justice Renato Corona is impeached by the Senate for failure to publicly disclose his statement of assets and liabilities.

media_caption: Church of Santo Domingo in Intramuros, Manila, ca 1910
text_description: Japanese war planes bomb Pearl Harbor, Sangley Point, Villamor Airbase, Clark Field, Intramuros, Subic, Baguio, and Davao. In Intramuros, the first to be bombed is the Santo Domingo church. War is declared on Japan by USA and the Philippines.

media_caption: Esteban Villanueva, Basi Revolt, 1 of 14, 1821 (Estrangulacion de los 4 Caudillos Insurgentes)
text_description: The Basi Revolt in Ilocos Norte occurs as protest against Spanish oppression.
The Philippine Revolution against Spain, led by Andres Bonifacio and the Katipunan, erupts in August 1896.

media_caption: Gregorio Aglipay, Obispo Maximo of the Philippine Independent Church
text_description: The Aglipayan Church is established by Isabelo de los Reyes (1864-1938) with Gregorio Aglipay as Obispo Maximo.

media_caption: National Arts Center in Laguna
media_credit: (Photo by Akio Kawasumi in The Architecture of Leandro V. Locsin by Nicholas Polites. John Weatherhill Inc, 1977.)
text_description: The Philippine High School for the Arts is founded. It will have scholars in the visual arts.

media_caption: Vicente Manansala, Jeepneys, 1951
text_description: Cubism is introduced through Pablo Picasso’s Les Demoiselles d'Avignon, 1907, and later by Georges Braque. Cubism will influence the work of Filipino artists such as Vicente Manansala (1910-1981), Cesar Legaspi (1917-1994), HR Ocampo (1911-1978), among others.

media_caption: Juvenal Sanso, Tree of Life
text_description: The Surrealism movement starts in France with the publication of the First Surrealist Manifesto by artists who want to explore artistic expressions based on dreams and the unconscious. The style of surrealism would later influence the art of Galo Ocampo and Juvenal Sanso, among others.

media_caption: 1924 Manila Carnival poster by Fernando Amorsolo
media_credit: (Copyright owned by Fernando C. Amorsolo Art Foundation, Inc; photo from Amorsolo: 1892-1972 by Alfredo Roces. Filipinas Foundation, Inc, 1975.)
text_description: The Manila Carnival is held annually at the Luneta Park. It combines a temporary theme park, beauty pageant, concert ground, trade fair, and exhibition venue. The carnival becomes a major venue for the development of the visual arts. Orchestral music is played at the coronation of carnival queens and the balls held in their honor.
