The Jabidah massacre happens and is later exposed.

media_caption: Guillermo Tolentino finishing a GSIS-commissioned sculpture of Ramon Magsaysay
media_credit: (Photo from Tolentino by Rodolfo Paras-Perez. National Art Foundation of Malolos, 1976.)
text_description: Ramon F. Magsaysay becomes president and serves until his death in a plane crash.

media_caption: Demonstrators holding a vandalized portrait of Imelda Marcos in front of Malacañan Palace, Feb 1986, EDSA Revolution
text_description: Feb 22-26: In protest against the election results as announced by Marcos, protesters congregate in EDSA to support Enrile and Ramos who rebel against Marcos.

media_caption: Depiction of a noble Tagalog couple, ca 1590
media_credit: (Boxer Codex, The Lilly Library Digital Collections)
text_description: Musée du quai Branly in Paris exhibits “Philippines: Archipel des échanges” (Philippines: An Archipelago of Exchange), which features artifacts and rare ethnographic materials on the Philippines.

media_caption: Ambahan chanting and inscription with Gawad sa Manlilikha ng Bayan awardee, Ginaw Bilog, right, ca 1993
text_description: Gawad sa Manlilikha ng Bayan or National Living Treasures Award is established. Ginaw Bilog (1953 - 2003) from the Hanunuo Mangyan of Oriental Mindoro becomes the first recipient for his practice of ambahan poetry and surat mangyan.

media_caption: Lipang Kalabaw, a politically oriented periodical
text_description: Mass-produced magazines such as Philippine Magazine, 1904; Excelsior and Philippines Free Press, both in 1905, and Lipang Kalabaw, 1907, are published.

media_caption: Ruins of the first San Ignacio Church, ca 1880
media_credit: Photo by Francisco Van Camp, John Tewell Collection
text_headline: An earthquake hits Manila
text_description: An earthquake hits Manila.

media_caption: Kennon Road to Baguio, popularly known as the Zigzag, ca 1915
text_headline: Americans send an exploratory party to the highlands of Baguio under Dean C. Worcester and Gen Luke E. Wright.
text_description: Americans send an exploratory party to the highlands of Baguio under Dean C. Worcester and Gen Luke E. Wright.

media_caption: Houses in Teachers Camp
text_description: Teachers Camp in Baguio is founded. The first assembly of American school teachers is held during the summer break at the site of the camp, with teachers staying in tents, later in buildings aggregately called Teacher’s Camp.

media_caption: University of the Philippines along Padre Faura Street, Manila
media_credit: Philippine Picture Post Cards: 1900-1920 by Jonathan Best, The Bookmark, Inc, 1994
text_description: UP occupies buildings in Ermita along Padre Faura and Herran (Pedro Gil) Sts.

media_caption: Prewar Burnham Park in Baguio City
text_description: Baguio opens as the “Summer Capital of the Philippines” with government offices transferring to Baguio during summer.

media_caption: Gabaldon-type high school in Cebu
media_credit: Philippine Picture Post Cards: 1900-1920 by Jonathan Best, The Bookmark, Inc, 1994
text_description: Philippine Assembly Act 1801, known as The Gabaldon Act as it is sponsored by Isauro Gabaldon, provides funds for the construction of elementary and high schools all over the archipelago, following master plans prepared by the Bureau of Public Works. Filipinos will be served by the public school a literary diet consisting of English Romantic and Victorian poetry, Shakespeare, Longfellow, and fiction with “local color” like the works of Bret Harte and Mark Twain, among others. The Gabaldon schools, built between 1907 and 1914, become the venue for music education for Filipino students.

media_caption: Metropolitan Theater, ca 1930
media_credit: Colorized by Bilog Bilugan, John Tewell Collection
text_description: Art Deco appears in Europe. Considered an innovative and avant garde style in keeping with the development of modern technology like the oceangoing luxury liners, the railroad system and cars, this style gains international recognition and exposure the following year.
Joseph Estrada, actor, is elected president of the Philippines.

media_caption: Cathedral of Our Lady of the Atonement
text_description: Baguio is raised to an Apostolic Prefecture in 1932 and to an Apostolic Vicariate in 1946. In 1992, the Apostolic Vicariates of Bontoc-Lagawe and Tabuk are separated from Baguio. In 2004, Baguio becomes a diocese, suffragan of the Archdiocese of Vigan.

media_caption: Prewar Colegio Seminario de San Carlos
media_credit: Cebuano Studies Center, University of San Carlos
text_description: The Colegio de San Carlos, Cebu, both seminary and college, are turned over to the Society of the Divine Word (SVD), who build a new campus on Rosario St.

media_caption: American-period street scene in Iloilo
text_description: Iloilo is made a chartered city of the Philippine Commonwealth, incorporating Arevalo, Jaro, La Paz, Mandurriao, and Molo.

media_caption: Jaro bell tower and church, ca 1920
text_description: The devastating Lady Caycay earthquake devsstates homes and buildings in Iloilo, like the Jaro Catheral and the Neogothic church of Oton, the masterpiece of Augustinian architecture in Panay Island.

media_caption: Pope John Paul II during his visit to Manila, 1995
media_credit: Photo courtesy of Eduardo de Leon
text_description: Pope John Paul II (1920-2005) visits the Philippines. The Pope stays at the Apostolic Nunciature, not the Coconut Palace.

media_caption: Prewar cottages in Camp John Hay
text_description: Camp John Hay in Baguio is returned to the Philippine government by the US military.

media_caption: PETA’s Kalayaan, an anti-Marcos street play, with protest leaders seated at far right, from right, Lorenzo Tañada, Corazon C. Aquino, Diosdado Macapagal, and Armando Malay, Post Office Building Manila, 1983
media_credit: (William Tan, photo courtesy of Nicanor G. Tiongson Collection)
text_description: Corazon Aquino leads massive protest demonstrations.

media_caption: Art deco Luis U. Santos Mansion, 2017
text_description: Exposition Internationale des Arts Decoratifs et Industriels Modernes opens in France and popularizes Art Deco. Art deco will arrive in the Philippines in the late 1920s but will be popular in the 1930s.

media_caption: Nora Aunor and Rita Avila in The Flor Contemplacion Story, 1995
text_description: Flor Contemplacion, a Filipino working as a domestic in Singapore, is executed. She becomes a symbol of the Filipino overseas worker and inspires literary works.

media_caption: Magsaysay family portrait with Pres Ramon Magsaysay, in barong tagalog, First Lady Luz Magsaysay in terno, and daughters in western dresses, ca 1955
text_description: Riding on his success, with Lansdale’s assistance, in effecting the surrender of the Hukbalahap, Ramon Magsaysay is elected president.

media_caption: UGATLahi Artist Collective, Gloria Fly Away, 2007
text_description: Macapagal Arroyo’s legitimacy as president is questioned when a recording of a conversation between her and an election commissioner is leaked to the public. More scandals will follow.

media_caption: Main building of the University of Santo Tomas in Sampaloc, Manila; below: Spanish-period University of Santo Tomas in Intramuros
media_credit: (Archivo de la Universidad de Santo Tomas)
text_description: The Colegio de Nuestra Señora del Santisimo Rosario is founded through the benefaction of Abp Miguel de Benavides, OP (r. 1603-1605). Initially a boarding school, it will be renamed Colegio de Santo Tomas and in 1645 will be declared a university, the oldest existing one in Asia. It will graduate many important Filipino writers up to the present.

media_caption: Diosdado Lorenzo, Atrocities in Paco, 1947
text_description: The “Battle of Manila” devastates the southern side of Manila, particularly Intramuros and the Taft corridor, in ruins. It will later inspire literary works about the war.

media_caption: Cris Pasturan and Ony de Leon in Tanghalang Pilipino’s Ars Poetica, CCP, Manila, 2006
text_description: The first Virgin Labfest unfolds at CCP under Tanghalang Pilipino.

media_caption: Pres Ferdinand Marcos and his generals on national television during the 1986 EDSA Revolt
text_description: Marcos calls for “snap elections” with him and Arturo Tolentino running against Corazon Aquino and Salvador Laurel for the presidency and vice presidency.

media_caption: Insignia of the Order of National Artist
text_description: Marcos issues Proclamation No. 1001, creating the National Artist Awards, with painter Fernando Amorsolo as its first recipient.

media_caption: Marcelo H. del Pilar, Literary figures during the Spanish period
text_description: Marcelo H. del Pilar leaves for Spain to avoid arrest.
US President William McKinley establishes the Taft Commission, also known as the Second Philippine Commission, the first legislative body of the Philippines.

media_caption: Pres. Macario Sakay, seated second from right, and the top generals of the Republika ng Katagalugan, 1906
media_credit: (National Historical Commission of the Philippines, Wikimedia Commons)
text_description: Macario Sakay is executed with many of his followers.
The Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature institutes an award for the full-length play category, in Filipino and English.
World War I occurs in Europe. The great losses that resulted from the global conflict would influence thinkers and artists.
Dada artist Marcel Duchamp’s The Fountain, a urinal, is accepted as an art work at the Museum. As a found object or readymade, the event highlights the shifting definition of art in the 20th century.

media_caption: RCA Victor Television set, 1952
text_description: Television sets become popular appliances especially in the urban areas.
Human migration from mainland Asia, via China and Taiwan to the Pacific and Oceania.
Palihang Aurelio V. Tolentino (PAVT), a playwriting workshop and contest designed and coordinated by a group led by Nicanor G. Tiongson (1946 - ), is inaugurated.
The women’s right to vote is granted by a nationwide plebiscite.
Philippine independence is proclaimed by President Truman.
The Batasang Pambansa sets the date of the Snap Election.
The Vietnam War ends with the defeat of US Forces.

media_caption: View of prewar Iloilo City
text_headline: Iloilo port is opened to international trade, facilitating the export of sugar.
text_description: Iloilo port is opened to international trade, facilitating the export of sugar.
Early hunters and gatherers settle in the Philippine islands, reaching Palawan.

Austronesian-speaking peoples settle in the islands, practicing horticulture and boat-making. The development of maritime knowledge equips the early inhabitants of the Philippine islands to travel by boat over Island Southeast Asia and the Pacific.
A trade network for jade between the Philippines, Taiwan, southern Vietnam, southern Thailand, and Cambodia is established.
Chinese migrants fleeing from the Fukien province settle in the Parian. Called sangleys, the Chinese artisans are conscripted to work for the church.
Gov Gen Luis Gomez Perez Dasmariñas orders the printing of religious books to convert the native population.
The San Diego galleon sinks near Fortune Island, Batangas when it clashes with the Dutch ship Mauritius.
Baroque art flourishes in Europe, including Spain. It affects “colonial art” in the Philippines beginning in the 17th century.
Rococo art becomes the favored art style of the aristocrats in Europe; it features excessive ornamentation in architecture and paintings.
The Dagohoy revolt in Bohol led by Francisco Dagohoy lasts for decades.
The 1750 Real Orden restricts artistic productions in colonial society, requiring artists to obtain ecclesiastical permission to make art.
The government monopolies of basi and tobacco enrich a few Spaniards but exploit the natives.
Neo-Classicism and Romanticism rise in Europe and the Americas.

The opening of the ports of Manila in 1834 leads to the participation in international trade of the Chinese mestizos who become the new elite. Ports also open in 1855 in Sual, Pangasinan, Iloilo and Zamboanga; 1860 in Cebu; and 1873 in Legazpi and Tacloban.
Due to the increase of trading activity, foreigners seek souvenirs in the form of paintings of native inhabitants.
Nov 17: The opening of the Suez Canal in 1869 contributes to the wealth of the mestizo class. The elite also send their children abroad to study, acquiring western ideals and aesthetics.
The style of Impressionism develops in Europe, influencing artists to observe the properties of light on color
The first exhibit of Impressionism opens in France and the style will influence Luna and Hidalgo.
Filipino participation at the Philadelphia Universal Exposition signifies the acceptance of the Filipinos talent in the academic art style.

media_caption: Reformists Jose Rizal, Marcelo H. Del Pilar, and Mariano Ponce, 1887
text_description: The Reform movement in Europe gathers strength. Filipino ilustrados work for reform through publications and organizational work.
William Taft becomes the first civil governor of the Philippines.
The British loot churches and houses in Manila. Some looted items eventually turn up in museums and private collections.

media_caption: Salon de Estudio, Ateneo Municipal de Manila (now Ateneo de Manila), ca 1887
text_description: The Jesuits take over the Escuela Pia, which later becomes the Ateneo Municipal and then the Ateneo de Manila. It will graduate many important writers, including Jose Rizal.
Art Nouveau becomes popular in Europe and the United States of America as a decorative style that draws inspiration from plants and organic forms.

media_caption: The inauguration of Malolos Congress, 1898
media_credit: (Colorized by the Official Gazette of the Republic of the Philippines)
text_description: The Malolos Congress opens.

Art Deco movement flourishes in Europe and the United States. It emphasizes rhythmic diagonal lines, geometric patterns, and the rigid rendering of anatomy. The first exhibit to embrace the ideals of Art Deco is the Exposition des Arts Décoratifs et Industriels Modernes held in Paris in 1925. Art Deco will arrive in the Philippines in the late 1920s but will be popular in the 1930s.
Camilo Osias authors The Philippine Reader(s) series, a primary instructional material containing stories and poems for Filipino elementary pupils.
The magazine Silew is founded.
The First Makiisa Festival: People’s Cultural Festival is held at Fort Santiago, Manila, with film screenings, stage performances of plays, skits, poetry, and songs.
The Armory Show at the Museum of Modern Art in New York launches modern art, influencing Victorio Edades (1895-1985) who saw the travelling exhibition in 1922.
Filipino Heritage gets launched despite Marcos’s threats on editor, Alfredo Roces.

media_caption: University of Santo Tomas College of Fine Arts and Design, 2016
text_description: The University of Santo Tomas College of Fine Arts and Design is founded. Its first faculty consists of Victorio Edades, Jose L. de Ocampo, and Severino Fabie.
The Korean War ends.
The newspaper Tribune is founded.
The Kapisanan sa Paglilingkod sa Bagong Pilipinas (KALIBAPI) is created by the Japanese.

media_caption: Justice for Aquino, Justice for All mural, 1983
media_credit: (Photo courtesy of Bantayog ng mga Bayani Foundation)
text_description: Protest movements such as the August Twenty-One Movement (ATOM), the Justice for Aquino, Justice for All (JAJA), and the Coalition for the Restoration of Democracy (CORD) are formed.
The Second Makiisa Festival of People’s Culture is held at the Christ the King Seminary, Sta. Mesa, Manila.
Cold War geopolitical conditions would influence art practices and policies between allies of the USA and USSR.
Abstract expressionism and avant-garde will develop in the USA in the 1940s aided by European artists who migrated to New York to escape the war.
In the 1950s, Filipino artists study abroad on travel and study grants, to Spain, France, Italy, Canada and the United States, which expose them to new trends in the West.

The publication Life magazine which was brought into the country after the war, features the works of Picasso, Braque, Chagall, Kandinsky, Mondrian, Buffet, and Dubuffet, and the New York abstract expressionists. Life fuels the popularity of modern art among Filipino artists.
Postwar reconstruction and the thrust toward national identity construction continue.
Philippine Art Gallery is founded by a group of women writers headed by Lydia Villanueva-Arguilla.
Philippine Women’s University School of Fine Arts and Design is founded. It will become the home of the Philippine Association of Printmakers (PAP) for many years.
Assemblage or “putting together” is used by French artist Jean Dubuffet and becomes popular in America.
The UP Department of Humanities is founded. Later renamed Department of Art Studies in 1989, it will become one of the core sites for producing art history and criticism in the country.
A wave of gallery building occurs in Manila and newer cosmopolitan areas like Makati. The new galleries include the Lopez Museum, Ateneo Art Gallery, and Luz Gallery.
Conceptual art gains currency with the publication of Sol LeWitt's 1967 article "Paragraphs on Conceptual Art" in Artforum.

Kabataang Makabayan (Nationalist Youth) or KM is founded by Jose Ma. Sison. Informed by the doctrines of Karl Marx, Vladimir Lenin, and Mao Zedong, KM is mobilized in the larger context of an international radicalized student movement in the late 1960s and 1970s.
Talks at the Yenan Forum by Mao Zedong gets circulated among activist groups.
The Design Center of the Philippines is established, further mainstreaming the role of culture in the Marcos government’s politico-development strategy.
The Marcos constitution is passed, paving the way for an authoritarian government.
The Tripoli Agreement is signed by the Philippine Government, the MNLF, and the Islamic Conference which provides for an autonomous region for Muslims in Southern Philippines among its provision.
The Marcos government’s political repression and outward-oriented policies fuel opposition aboveground and underground.

The price of cane sugar drops in the world market and plunges the Philippine sugar industry into a grave crisis, resulting in hunger and poverty of farmers in provinces dedicated to sugar farming such as Negros Occidental.
Many families in Bacolod lose their loved ones when MV Don Juan sinks, adding more gloom to the depressed situation of the Negrense.
President Marcos secretly undergoes a kidney transplant.
The Concerned Artists of the Philippines is founded, composed of writers, artists, and cultural workers who oppose the Marcos dictatorship and fight for the freedom of expression.

Groups opposing the Marcos dictatorship band together to form protest organizations such as the August Twenty-One Movement (ATOM), the Justice for Aquino, Justice for All (JAJA), and the Coalition for the Restoration for Democracy (CORD). Corazon Aquino leads a massive rally to commemorate her husband’s killing.
Labor leader Rolando Olalia is assassinated.
The Presidential Commission on Culture and the Arts (PCCA) is established under the Executive Order 118.
Student activist Lean Alejandro is assassinated.

The Jorge Vargas Museum is formally inaugurated in UP Diliman, housing the Vargas art collections consisting of paintings, sculptures, stamps, coins and memorabilia, the core of which are from the Commonwealth era to post-WWII period.
The Gawad CCP para sa Sining is established, combining, synthesizing, and expanding all previous CCP awards for lifetime achievement in the arts.
First Fukuoka Asian Art Show is held in Japan. It later becomes the Fukuoka Asian Art Triennale, where Philippine artists are regularly represented.

Created by law, the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) replaces the PCCA. THE NCCA has a national Visual Arts committee that recommends artists for production, venue, and travel grants.
The First Asia Pacific Triennale is held in Australia, where there is consistent recognition of art from the Philippines.
The centennial of Philippine independence is celebrated.
Cubism in Asia exhibit, which includes art from the Philippines, opens in Tokyo and travels to Singapore and Paris up to 2007.

The decade is characterized by the growing interest of auction houses Sotheby’s and Christies’ in Asian art. Artworks from Filipino artists fetch significant prices, such as the works of Botong Francisco, HR Ocampo, Bencab, Anita Magsaysay Ho, and Ronald Ventura (b. 1973).
Farmers protesting the government’s lack of action in land reform are violently dispersed by the police, resulting in what is dubbed as the ‘Mendiola Massacre.’
President Aquino issues EO 118 establishing the Presidential Commission for Culture and the Arts to coordinate activities of existing cultural and historical institutions.
Bugkos, a national alliance of cause-oriented theater and cultural groups is formalized.
A magnitude 7.8 earthquake hits Luzon and propels artists to embark on community work in the midst of recovery and reconstruction in Baguio.
The CCP Encyclopedia of Philippine Art is published. It is composed of volumes on Peoples, Architecture, Visual Arts, Film, Music, Dance, Theater, and Literature.

The limited number of secular priests in the islands prompts Pope Pius V to allow the regular clergy to serve as parish priests. Dispute between them and the bishops will eventually ensue, with the expulsion of the Jesuits in 1768 providing an impetus for secularization.

A series of naval battles between the Spaniards and the Dutch ensues, with Spanish victory attributed to the intercession of the Virgin Mary. The event is celebrated in the Feast of La Naval de Manila.

A royal decree orders the secularization of parishes. Filipino secular priests, however, are ill trained, and in 1776 another decree will reverse secularization, although it will also insist on the visitation of parishes run by the regular clergy by either the archbishop or the superior of the order. The Spanish regular clergy will increasingly acquire more parishes at the expense of Filipino priests, justifying desecularization with the return of the Jesuits in 1859.

The Educational Decree of 1863 mandates the establishment of a public school system and the founding of a normal school for teachers, effecting in part the secularization of education in the Philippines.
Doña Perfecta, a novel by Benito Perez Galdos, is published, an example of realism in Spain. It will influence Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere.
Filipino expatriates in Spain start the Propaganda Movement, founding various civic organizations and writing pamphlets and articles to push for reforms.
The sole issue of Kalayaan, the organ of the Katipunan, is published, increasing membership in the Katipunan. The issue is dated Jan 18.
Rizal is executed by firing squad. More arrests, tortures, and executions of known liberals or suspected Katipuneros follow.
The USS Maine sinks, triggering the Spanish-American war, among the results of which will be the annexation of the Philippines by the United States.

The Treaty of Paris is signed, Spain ceding the Philippines to the United States for twenty million dollars. The end of the Spanish-American war, however, will lead to the Philippine-American war in 1899.
The Sedition Law is passed, penalizing anyone attacking the United States or fighting for Philippine independence.

The Pensionado Act is passed, designed to form Americanized leaders in the colony by having select Filipinos study in the United States, a phenomenon dramatized in the novel His Native Soil (1941) by Juan Laya (1911-52).
The Flag Law is passed, forbidding the public display of the Philippine flag, one of the measures enacted by the American colonial government to suppress nationalism.
The Hukbalahap is outlawed.
American forces defeat the Spanish at the Battle of Manila. The Spanish governor-general surrenders Intramuros to the Americans, not to Aguinaldo.
The Philippine Senate, headed by Sen. Jovito Salonga, rejects the renewal of the US Military Bases Agreement first ratified in 1947. Clark Air Base closes.
The systematic Christianization and colonization of the Philippines begin with the arrival of Miguel Lopez de Legazpi and the Augustinians under Fr Andres Urdaneta.
The Philippines Free Press is bought by R. McCulloch Dick and F. Theo Rogers. Initially a bilingual (Spanish-English) weekly news magazine, it will later feature new literature by Filipinos.
Imagism is officially introduced with the publication of poems by H.D. and Richard Aldington in Poetry. It will influence many Filipino poets.
CCP launches the Unang Tagpo: National Theater Festival.

The Philippine Library and Museum is established, later to be separated into the National Museum and the National Library. The Library provides writers an alternative literary fare from that given by the public schools, its holding of foreign magazines like the Dial exposing them to modern authors and to modernism.
The Fundacion Zobel is established to promote Spanish in the Philippines.

media_caption: National Artist for Theater Design Salvador Bernal awarded in 2003
text_description: Philippine Association of Theatre Designers and Technicians – Organization Internationale des Scenographes, Techniciens et Architects de Theatre (PATDAT – OISTAT) is organized by Salvador F. Bernal.
Poor living conditions lead to peasant unrest in Mindanao. Social injustice will persist all over the country and be a recurring theme in Philippine literature.
Members of the Philippine Labor Congress (PLC) form the Labor Party.

The US stock market crashes, ushering in the Great Depression. The economic downturn will increase the appeal of Communism and cause a reorientation among writers in the United States. A similar reexamination of the social function of literature will occur in Philippine literature in the 1930s.
The Socialist Party is founded by Pedro Abad Santos.

Crisanto Evangelista and Jacinto Manahan found the Partido Komunista ng Pilipinas. The party aims to end American overlordship and improve the living conditions of peasants and laborers. It will be declared illegal in 1932.
Benigno Ramos (1892-1946) founds the Sakdal movement in reaction to incidence of racial discrimination. The movement seeks immediate Philippine independence from the United States.

The Tydings-McDuffie Law is passed, providing for Philippine independence after a ten-year transition period. The struggle for independence has resulted in the exploration of what is Filipino in art and literature, manifesting as “local color” in the works of Casiano Calalang and Manuel Arguilla.
The League of American Writers, funded by the Communist Party of the United States, is established, promoting proletarian literature and later anti-Fascist literature.

After feverish campaign by women leaders, the suffrage bill becomes law. Writers like Rosa Sevilla (1879-1954), Encarnacion Alzona (1895-2001), Trinidad Tarrosa Subido (1912-94) are some of the prominent suffragettes.
Japanese forces land in Bataan. Manila will be declared an open city on Dec 26.
The magazines Pillars and Philippine Review are founded, affording writers in English an outlet for their creations.
The United States uses the atomic bomb on Hiroshima and Nagasaki. The Japanese surrender.

The Philippine Assembly is inaugurated with Filipino representatives, effectively ending the Philippine-American war. The leadership and composition of the Philippine Assembly would define the emergence of cacique-led democracy in Philippine politics. The major resistance against American colonization begins to wane.

The College Folio, the first campus magazine advocating the use of the English language, is published by students of the University of the Philippines. It will publish retellings of folktales and prose and poetry by Fernando Maramag (1893-1936) and Maximo Kalaw (1891-1955), among other writers.
Makinaugalingon, an Ilonggo nationalist newspaper, is founded by Rosendo Mejica (1873-1956).
James Joyce’s Ulysses and T. S. Eliot’s The Wasteland are published, marking the high tide of literary modernism. It will influence Filipino writers later.
The newspaper Philippines Herald is founded.

The Cold War begins, with the United States deploying both hard and soft tactics to contain the spread of Communism, leading to “witch hunts” in the 1950s. Creative writing workshops and exchange programs, funded by state agencies and foundations committed to fighting Communism, will be implicated in the ideological war.
Mao Zedong declares the foundation of the People’s Republic of China. Maoist thought will influence Filipino writers in the 1970s and give rise to student activism.

The Korean War begins, to which the Philippines sends troops. It will end with the division of Korea into the Communist North and the “free” South. Edward Lansdale creates the USIS and intensifies anti-Communist propaganda. The decade will witness the crackdown on progressive writers at the University of the Philippines.
James Dean’s movie Rebel without a Cause introduces the theme of the rebellious teenager in Philippine literature.

Jose Ma. Sison and others form the Communist Party of the Philippines (CPP), with the goal of defeating “imperialism, feudalism, and bureaucrat capitalism” and overthrowing the state. It will form its military arm, the New People’s Army (NPA), in 1969. In 1973, its political arm, the National Democratic Front (NDF), will be established.

Marcos signs the Vietnam Aid Law. Later in the year, he hosts the Manila Summit with US President Lyndon Johnson in attendance. Students rally in front of the US Embassy to protest the Summit. More such protests will occur throughout the decade. Filipinization, in the form of criticism of US influence in national life and politics, will become a force, and the radicalization of students, a theme in Philippine literature.
The Philippines’s labor export policy begins as a stop-gap measure to address the country’s unemployment woes, trade deficits, and ballooning external debt.
CCP honors the most important artists and cultural workers of the past century with the CCP Centennial Honors for the Arts.
Sagisag magazine is founded. It will publish literary and critical pieces.
The Book Development Association of the Philippines is established.
The Coalition of Writers and Artists for Freedom and Democracy declares its support for Marcos and Tolentino in a full-page ad in a newspaper.

The fourth and most serious of coup attempt of the year occurs. A group of army officers and soldiers, called Reform the Armed Forces Movement (RAM), seize several facilities and attack Malacañan Palace.
Aquino signs the Comprehensive Agrarian Reform Law, but agrarian problems will persist, as the so-called Hacienda Luisita massacre will testify in 2004.

The National Centennial Commission is formed to celebrate the centennial of the Philippine independence and the Malolos Congress. It organizes many commissions and competitions, including the Centennial Literary Prize.
Republic Act 8047 creates the National Book Development Board, which in 2008 will merge with the Manila Critics Circle in handing out the National Book Awards.
For the first time in Asia, an elected president, Joseph Ejercito Estrada, is tried and impeached.
The government sign a peace agreement with the Moro National Liberation Front (MNLF).
The centenary of the Malolos Republic is celebrated.
Estrada declares “all-out-war” against the Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF).
A group of military officers and soldiers stage a mutiny in a hotel in Makati City.
The government signs a framework for a peace plan with the MILF. It seeks the creation of an autonomous region to be called Bangsamoro.
John Logie Baird produces the first live moving TV image from London.
Philo T. Farnsworth transmits the first TV electrical signals without the use of mechanical equipment from San Francisco.
Pres. Laurel delivers a speech over PIAM in celebration of Greater East Asia Day.

media_caption: President Jose P. Laurel, 1953, by Fernando Amorsolo
media_credit: (Copyright owned by the Fernando C. Amorsolo Art Foundation, Inc)
text_description: Pres. Laurel declares war against the US and Great Britain over PIAM.
Marcos calls for a Constitutional Convention.

media_caption: Funeral procession of Benigno Aquino Jr along Rizal Park, Manila, 1983
text_headline: NINOY'S ASSASSINATION
text_description: Benigno "Ninoy" Aquino is assassinated as he disembarks from China Airlines at the Manila International Airport. From hereon, protests against Marcos grow rapidly, even as the economy deteriorates.

media_caption: Funeral procession of Benigno Aquino Jr along Rizal Park, Manila, 1983
text_description: Government investigation convicts military officers for the assassination of Benigno Aquino.

media_caption: 1986 EDSA Revolt
text_description: Although Marcos is declared the winner of the elections on Feb. 15, the EDSA People Power Revolution ousts Marcos and installs Corazon Aquino as the president of the Philippines on Feb 25. The new “democratic space” results in more literary production. The government, however, will be plagued by coup d’états, the first happening within months of Aquino’s installation.

media_caption: Sergio Osmeña sworn into office as president of the Philippines by Gen Arthur MacArthur at the Leyte Capitol Building, 23 Oct 1944
text_headline: Upon the death of Quezon, Sergio Osmeña becomes president of the Philippine Commonwealth.
text_description: Upon the death of Quezon, Sergio Osmeña becomes president of the Philippine Commonwealth. He serves until 1946.

media_caption: Fleur de Lis (Mona Lisa) and Ely Ramos in Giliw Ko, 1939
text_description: The big three studios Sampaguita, LVN, and Premiere produce genre movies, including musicals.

media_caption: Pastores performing a villancico, Camalig, Albay, ca 1990
text_headline: Spain develops villancicos.
text_description: Spain develops villancicos.

media_caption: Liwayway ng Kalayaan, 1944
text_description: Importation of film stock is forbidden by the Japanese. Local filmmaking stops.

media_caption: Luis Taruc, standing on the right, with members of the Hukbo ng Bayan Laban sa mga Hapon or HUKBALAHAP
text_description: Hukbong Mapaglaya ng Bayan (from an earlier movement Hukbo ng Bayan Laban sa Hapon) is organized to continue the peasant rebellion against social injustice in Central Luzon.
After the war, control over radio is returned to private hands, beginning a vibrant radio industry in the US.

text_headline: With the coming of sound, the major film companies are established.
text_description: With the coming of sound, the major film companies are established, among them Filippine Films (1933), Sampaguita Pictures (1937), Excelsior Pictures (1938), and LVN Pictures (1938).
Guglielmo Marconi develops the first effective radio communication system in Italy, which he brings to Britain.

media_caption: Pres Manuel L. Quezon at KZRH explaining the law he signed proclaiming Tagalog as basis of the national language, 1938
text_description: Pres. Quezon declares Tagalog as basis for the national language.

media_caption: The inauguration of Malolos Congress, 1899
media_credit: (Colorized by the Official Gazette of the Republic of the Philippines)
text_headline: Emilio Aguinaldo is sworn in as the president of the first Philippine Republic in Malolos.
text_description: Emilio Aguinaldo is sworn in as the president of the first Philippine Republic in Malolos.

media_caption: Album cover of Francis Magalona’s Yo!, 1990, which includes “Mga Kababayan Ko”
text_description: Master Rapper Francis Magalona aka the Man from Manila and his crew The Eclipse (b-boy crew) and Spindicate Posse (DJ crew), which includes pioneer turntablist Dj Master of Disaster or Dj MOD, releases the song “Mga Kababayan,” ushering in the so-called Golden Age of Hip-hop.
The United States declares war on Germany, and the US Navy takes control of private radio stations, leading to the rapid development of radio.
CBS airs the first live radio broadcast of the New York Philharmonic Orchestra.
Adolf Hitler is appointed Chancellor of Germany; he is one of the first leaders to use radio for propaganda.
Pres. Quezon creates the Radio Board (RB) to nationalize radio stations in the colony.
Orson Welles airs HG Wells’s War of the Worlds on CBS radio in the style of news bulletins, about a Martian invasion, panicking listeners.
The World’s Fair in New York City features the first exhibition of TV in the World of Tomorrow Pavilion. TV will not be introduced in the Philippines until 1953.
Pres. Quezon transfers the Radio Control Division (RCD) to the Department of National Defense in anticipation of war.
The first US TV commercial, an ad of Bulova watch, airs on WNBT.
Pres. Quezon, Vice Pres. Sergio Osmeña, and their families are evacuated to the US.
Gen. MacArthur is evacuated to Australia.
The Japanese capture Corregidor and Cebu.
Commander of the Japanese forces in the Philippines Gen Masaharu Homma lays the guidelines for culture and education in order to build a “New Philippines.”

media_caption: Jose P. Laurel, 1953, by Fernando Amorsolo
media_credit: (Copyright owned by the Fernando C. Amorsolo Art Foundation, Inc)
text_description: Pres. Laurel dissolves his government.
Pres. Macapagal Issues Proclamation Number 28, moving independence day from July 4 back to June 12.
The Sony Trinitron color television set makes its world debut, surpassing previous color TV technologies.
Gloria Diaz becomes the first Filipino to be crowned Miss Universe.
Audiences around the world watch the lunar landing of Apollo 11 on live television via satellite.
The world watches the television coverage of the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich, West Germany, including the massacre of 11 Israeli athletes and coaches by Palestinian gunmen.
Over 20,000 Filipinos and members of 50 indigenous groups parade in a ceremony dubbed Kasaysayan ng Lahi, culminating with the inauguration of the Folk Arts Theater.
Elections for the Interim Batasang Pambansa are held. Prior to the election, Ninoy Aquino campaigns from prison. Noise barrages signal the growing protest against martial law.
Marcos lifts martial law through Proclamation 2045, but many of the structures of martial law remain until his downfall.

The EDSA People Power revolt begins. Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile and Armed Forces of the Philippines Vice Chief of Staff and Philippine Constabulary Chief Fidel V Ramos withdraw support from Marcos.
A nationwide plebiscite ratifies the 1987 Philippine Constitution.
CCP mounts the first Arts Month to celebrate the 1986 EDSA revolt. From here on, February will be celebrated as arts month by other cultural institutions.
The Senate files an impeachment case against Pres. Estrada on corruption charges.
Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo is inaugurated President. She finishes the three remaining years in Estrada’s term.
Arroyo is inaugurated as President following her election. Supporters of her opponent, film actor and producer FPJ, allege cheating.
Fidel V. Ramos is inaugurated President and serves until 1998.

In a TV broadcast Pres Arroyo responds to the “Hello Garci” wiretapping scandal, admits the conversation with former Election Commissioner Virgilio Garcillano, but denies manipulation of election results.
The Human Rights Watch notes that in 2013, 12 journalists in the Philippines are killed, the highest number in a single year since 2009.
The Supreme Court of the Philippines declares the major provisions of the Cybercrime Prevention Act of 2012, including the online libel provision, as constitutional.
With his interpreter Enrique, Magellan reaches Homonhon on Mar 16.

media_caption: Pres. Emilio Aguinaldo
media_credit: (Colorized by the Official Gazette of the Republic of the Philippines)
text_description: In Kawit Cavite, Emilio Aguinaldo declares Philippine independence. The proclamation is later ratified by the Malolos Congress on Sept 29.

media_caption: President Macario Sakay, seated second from right, and the top generals of the Republika ng Katagalugan, 1906
media_credit: (National Historical Commission of the Philippines, Wikimedia Commons)
text_description: US President Theodore Roosevelt proclaims end of Philippine American war and grants amnesty to the Filipino fighters, but nationalist resistance continues in the countryside until 1907 under Macario Sakay and other revolutionary leaders.

media_caption: Igorot men performing at the St Louis World’s Fair, USA, 1904
text_description: In the St. Louis Exposition in Missouri, contingents of indigenous peoples composed of over a thousand from the Philippines are exotically displayed in recreations of “native villages” at the World’s Fair. Some of the groups are the Tagalog, Aeta, Bagobo, Mangyan, and Igorot.

media_caption: Santo Niño de Cebu
media_credit: (Photo from The Augustinian Province of Santo Niño de Cebu-Philippines Provincialate Offices)
text_description: Ferdinand Magellan gives the image of the Santo Niño to Hara Amihan (christened as Juana), wife of Rajah Humabon.
The Spanish bombard local settlements with artillery in retaliation against Humabon’s successor who is hostile to the invaders.
The 1987 Constitution declares Filipino as the national language of the Philippines, which should be developed based on other Philippine languages.
Several failed coup attempts instigated by a faction in the military are mounted against Pres. Corazon Aquino, including those where troops seize television stations in Manila.

The new CCP management appointed by Cory Aquino reorients the institution toward the thrusts of Filipinization, democratization, and decentralization. As the new coordinating center for the arts, CCP now includes an office and program that gives grants for writers, visual artists, and theater groups from Manila and the region, creates cultural programs on media. and gives out awards for radio and television.

National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) replaces PCCA under the Republic Act No. 7356. It will recommend artists and organizations, writers, and film projects for production, venue, and travel grants, and later recognize outstanding achievements in the arts.

media_caption: Church of the Inmaculada Concepcion in Guiuan, Eastern Samar, 2016
text_headline: Category 5 Typhoon Yolanda (international name Haiyan) hits the Philippines.
text_description: Category 5 Typhoon Yolanda (international name Haiyan) hits the Philippines. The typhoon is spotted on 3 Nov over the Pacific and in four days makes landfall at Guiuan, Samar. The Visayas, especially the Eastern Visayan islands of Samar and Leyte, are heavily damaged.
UP President Jorge Bocobo launches his project to gather Filipino folk songs and dances from all over the country.
Hitler and his Nazi Party in Germany invade Poland, an act that snowballs into World War II.

The first of the Chinese revolts erupts, protesting the worsening condition of the Chinese community. As a consequence of this and other revolts, the Chinese are moved to an enclave called Parian outside the walls of Intramuros. The riots are repeated in 1662-63, 1668 and 1762.

media_caption: Pres Manuel Roxas speaking on live broadcast during the declaration of Philippine Independence, 1946, as Vice Pres Elpidio Quirino, seated at left, looks on
media_credit: (Presidential Museum and Library of the Philippines)
text_description: The Third Republic of the Philippines is inaugurated with Manuel Roxas installed as president. The United States, however, continues to exert influence over the economy and US military bases are retained. He serves until 1948 when he dies of a heart attack.

media_caption: Jose P. Laurel being sworn in as president of the Japanese-sponsored Philippine republic, 1943,  aired over radio station PIAM
media_credit: Presidential Museum and Library of the Philippines
text_description: Jose P. Laurel becomes president of the Second Republic during the Japanese Occupation. He serves until 1945.

media_caption: Nationalist Claro M. Recto
media_credit: (Photo courtesy of National Library of the Philippines)
text_description: Claro M. Recto authors the Rizal Bill and Jose P. Laurel Sr. sponsors it. It is passed into law as Republic Act 1425 on June 16, 1956. The Rizal Law requires the study of Rizal’s life and works in all schools in the Philippines.

media_caption: Willie Vicoy, Vietnam War
text_description: The Vietnam War begins, with the intervention of deployed American soldiers. From 1964 to 1969, the Philippines will send troops to perform medical and civil propaganda operations as an ally of the United States. Filipino journalists are also sent to Vietnam.

Elpidio Quirino is sworn in as President of the Philippines after Roxas dies of a heart attack in Clark Field, Pampanga. Quirino finishes the remaining term of Roxas and gets reelected in the next term in which he serves until 1953.

media_caption: Renowned Filipino composers, from left, Lucrecia Kasilag, Rodolfo Cornejo, Lucino Sacramento, Antonio Molina, Eliseo Pajaro,  Antonino Buenaventura, Felipe Padilla de Leon, and Lucio San Pedro, 1956
text_description: The United States and the Philippines sign an agreement to establish the Fulbright scholarship program, an educational exchange program. It will provide scholarships for Filipinos to study in the United States. Among the recipients are Jose Joya (1931-1995) and Constancio Bernardo (1913-2003) for Visual Arts, Lucrecia Kasilag and Ramon Santos for Music, Francisco Arcellana, Bienvenido Santos (1911-96), and N. V. M. Gonzalez for Literature who are sent to the US to study.

media_caption: Facade and reflecting pool of the Cultural Center of the Philippines
media_credit: (Photo by Akio Kawasumi in The Architecture of Leandro V. Locsin by Nicholas Polites. John Weatherhill Inc, 1977.)
text_description: Amid protests, the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) is inaugurated. Chabet is the first Museum Director of the CCP, followed by Raymundo Albano (1947-1985) as Visual Arts Director. It will later have full-blown programs in visual arts, film, music, theater, dance, and literature.

media_caption: President Carlos P. Garcia
media_credit: (Copyright owned by the Fernando C. Amorsolo Art Foundation, Inc)
text_description: Carlos Garcia, author of “Dalagang Pilipinhon,” one of the best known poems in Cebuano literature, becomes the president of the Philippines upon the death of Magsaysay. He launches a “Filipino First” policy in the economy and government. Garcia gets re-elected for the next term and serves until 1961.

media_caption: Luis Taruc, reading a newspaper, with his troop, 1950
text_description: The Japanese Imperial Army formally occupies the Philippines. The following day, the commander in chief of the Japanese Imperial forces declare the end of American occupation, but guerrilla forces, especially the Hukbo ng Bayan Laban sa Hapon or Hukbalahap, continue the resistance. In line with its anti-Western agenda, the government suppresses English but supports Tagalog literature. Some Filipino writers switch mediums. After the war, the occupation engenders literary pieces.

text_headline: Manila port is opened to international trade.
text_description: Spain’s fiscal debility because of political upheavals in Spain and the diminishment of its empire through revolutions weakens its economic hold on the Philippines, making the islands a target for other enterprising Europeans, like the French, German, English and the rising power, USA.

media_caption: Lipang Kalabaw, American-period newspaper
media_credit: (Nicanor G. Tiongson Collection and Lopez Museum and Library)
text_description: The satirical weekly Lipang Kalabaw is founded. Periodicals like Telembang, Buntot Pague, and Pakakak will continue the tradition of political and social satire as the American occupation progresses.
